    var googletag = googletag || {};
    googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];

    function loadScriptDynamically(scriptUrl) {
        var gads = document.createElement('script'),
            node = document.getElementsByTagName('script') [0];
        gads.async = true;
        gads.src = scriptUrl;
        node.parentNode.insertBefore(gads, node);
    }

    loadScriptDynamically('https://securepubads.g.doubleclick.net/tag/js/gpt.js');
</script>

<script nonce="46a1cd22ceaf40d5adca4663cd8f0483">
    googletag.cmd.push(function () {
        var sizes = {
            leaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([320, 100], [[300, 50], [320, 50]])
                .addSize([740, 100], [728, 90])
                .addSize([0, 0], 'fluid')
                .build(),
            mobileleaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([300, 100], [300, 50])
                .addSize([320, 100], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            mobilefooter: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 50])
                .addSize([0, 0], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            rail: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 250])
                .build(),
            interstitial: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [640, 480])
                .build()
        };

        gptPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.page ? digitalData.page.page : "blank";
        gptSubPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.subPage ? digitalData.page.subPage : "blank";

        function gptClean(gptText) {
            if (typeof (gptText) == "string") {
                gptText = gptText.replace(/\&/g, '%26');
                return gptText.replace(/\^|\*|#|\$|\"|\'|\=|\,|\!|\+|\~|\;|\(|\)|\<|\>|\[|\]|\?|\%|\:|\@|\;|\&|\||\{|\}|\\|/g, '');
            }
            return "blank";
        }

        googletag.pubads()
            .setTargeting('property', 'value-of-property')    // Change and duplicate this line for as many additional keywords to send
            .setTargeting('doi', gptClean('10.1002/aenm.202302830')) // Publication DOI
            .setTargeting('pbPage', gptClean(gptPage))
            .setTargeting('pbSubPage', gptClean(gptSubPage))
            .setTargeting('urlpath', gptClean(document.location.pathname));

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-leaderboard')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.leaderboard)
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobileleaderboard)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobilefooter)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-1')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-1')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-2')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-2')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-video')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.interstitial)
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-video')
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);


        // googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();


        if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {
            // PERICLES-17135
            googletag.pubads().disableInitialLoad();
        }

        googletag.enableServices();
    });

    if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {

            apstag.fetchBids({timeout: 2000}, function (bids) {
                apstag.setDisplayBids();
                googletag.pubads().refresh();

    <!-- Get whether TNSI is in live or test mode -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI Javascript version number -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI MerchantID -->
    
    <!-- Add "TEST" to beginning of merchant ID when running in test mode -->
    

    
<!-- loading Javascript for using the persistence Service -->
    <script src="/templates/jsp/pb2/js/plugin/thiss-ds.js" nonce="46a1cd22ceaf40d5adca4663cd8f0483"></script>

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="46a1cd22ceaf40d5adca4663cd8f0483">

        function getParameter(parameterName) {
            let result = null,
                tmp = [];
            location.search
                .substr(1)
                .split("&")
                .forEach(function (item) {
                    tmp = item.split("=");
                    if (tmp[0] === parameterName) result = tmp[1];
                });
            return result;
        }

        var SeamlessAccessService = {
            spUrl: "/action/ssostart",
            returnURL: window.location.href,
            my_context: 'seamlessaccess.org',
            queryParamsDelimiter: encodeURIComponent('?'),

            getWAYFLessUrl: function (entityId) {
                let redirectURL = getParameter('redirectUri');
                if(redirectURL == null){
                    redirectURL = encodeURIComponent(this.returnURL);
                }
                if(redirectURL.indexOf('saml_referrer') < 0){
                    redirectURL += encodeURIComponent(((redirectURL.indexOf(this.queryParamsDelimiter) !== -1) ? '&' : '?') + 'saml_referrer');
                }
                return this.spUrl + "?idp=" + encodeURIComponent(entityId)
                    + "&redirectUri=" + redirectURL;
            },
            retrieveEntity: function () {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.entities(self.my_context)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // get the results
                            var results = res.data;
                            return resolve(results);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            reject('retrieve entity error: ' + err);
                        });
                });
            },
            updateEntity: function (entitydata) {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                var jsonObj = {};
                try {
                    //try to parse it, if it is a json string
                    jsonObj = JSON.parse(entitydata.val());
                } catch (e) {
                    jsonObj = entitydata;
                }
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.update(self.my_context, jsonObj)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // Process the results
                            var ssoInstitutions = res.data;
                            return resolve(ssoInstitutions);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to update the local storage duo to: ' + err);
                            reject(err);
                        });
                })
            },
            removeEntity: function (entityId) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    persistService.remove(self.my_context, entityId)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            return resolve(res);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to remove from local storage duo to: ' + err);
                        });
                })
            },
            getAccessibleEntityStatus: function (doi, entityId, entityTitle) {
                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    $.ajax({
                        type: 'POST',
                        url: '/action/seamlessAccess',
                        accept: {
                            text: "application/json"
                        },
                        data: {doi: doi, entityid: entityId, entityTitle: entityTitle, eventGroupKey: '599ba387-34ea-4750-acb6-766a97da15f8'}

                    }).done(function (status) {
                        return resolve(status);
                    });
                });
            },
            getEntitiesWithAllInfo: function (doi) {
                let self = this,
                    arrayOfPromises = [];
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    self.retrieveEntity().then(function (res) {
                        let allSsoInstitutions = res;
                        for (let i in allSsoInstitutions) {
                            let ssoInstitution = allSsoInstitutions[i];
                            arrayOfPromises.push(new Promise(function (resolve) {
                                self.getAccessibleEntityStatus(doi, ssoInstitution.entity.entityID, ssoInstitution.entity.title)
                                    .then(function (entityStatus) {
                                        resolve({
                                            entityID: ssoInstitution.entity.entityID,
                                            entityTitle: ssoInstitution.entity.title,
                                            entityStatusObj: entityStatus,
                                            entitySsoUrl: self.getWAYFLessUrl(ssoInstitution.entity.entityID)
                                        });
                                    }, function (err) {
                                        console.log('failed to get the entity status: ' + err);
                                    });
                            }));
                        }
                        Promise.all(arrayOfPromises)
                            .then(function (finalResponse) {
                                resolve(finalResponse);
                            });

                    }).catch(function (err) {
                        reject(err);
                    })
                });
            }
        };

        window.addEventListener('load', function () {
            document.querySelectorAll(".sso-institution").forEach(function (institution) {
                var entityId = institution.getAttribute('data-entityid');
                var entityName = institution.getAttribute('data-name');
                var entitydata = {
                    entityID: entityId,
                    title: entityName
                };
                institution.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    var self = this;
                    SeamlessAccessService.updateEntity(entitydata).then(function (res) {
                        console.log(res);
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    }).catch(function (err){
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    });
                });
            });
        });

    </script>

        (function() {
            function riskifiedBeaconLoad() {
                var store_domain = 'https://advanced.onlinelibrary.wiley.com';
                var session_id = '4BD0386CACCC12E11BB876F41F09FD53';
                var url = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://')
                    + "beacon.riskified.com?shop=" + store_domain + "&sid=" + session_id;
                var s = document.createElement('script');
                s.type = 'text/javascript';
                s.async = true;
                s.src = url;
                var x = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
                x.parentNode.insertBefore(s, x);
            }
            if (window.attachEvent)
                window.attachEvent('onload', riskifiedBeaconLoad)
            else
                window.addEventListener('load', riskifiedBeaconLoad, false);
        })();

                     <p>Institute of Physical Chemistry and Center for Materials Research, Justus Liebig University Giessen, Heinrich Buff Ring 17, 35392 Giessen, Germany</p><a class="moreInfoLink" href="/authored-by/Smarsly/Bernd">Search for more papers by this author</a></div></span><span class="accordion-tabbed__tab-mobile  accordion__closed"><a href="/authored-by/Rohnke/Marcus" class="author-name accordion-tabbed__control" data-id="a27" data-db-target-for="a27" aria-controls="a27" aria-haspopup="true" id="a27_Ctrl" role="button"><span>Marcus Rohnke<i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-mail_outline"></i></span><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-section_arrow_d"></i></a><span class="comma-separator">,&nbsp;</span><div class="author-info accordion-tabbed__content" data-db-target-of="a27" aria-labelledby="a27_Ctrl" role="region" id="a27">
                     <p class="author-type mb-1">Corresponding Author</p>
                     <p class="author-name">Marcus Rohnke</p>
                     <ul class="rlist sm-account">
                        <li class="sm-account__item"><a class="sm-account__link" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:marcus.rohnke@phys.chemie.uni-giessen.de"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-ic_mail_solid"></i><span>marcus.rohnke@phys.chemie.uni-giessen.de</span></a></li>
                     </ul>
                     <ul class="rlist sm-account">
                        <li class="sm-account__item"><a target="_blank" class="sm-account__link" href="https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8867-950X"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-orcid"></i><span>orcid.org/0000-0002-8867-950X</span></a></li>
                     </ul>
                     <p>Institute of Physical Chemistry and Center for Materials Research, Justus Liebig University Giessen, Heinrich Buff Ring 17, 35392 Giessen, Germany</p>
                     <p>E-mail: <a class="corr-email" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:marcus.rohnke@phys.chemie.uni-giessen.de"><span>marcus.rohnke@phys.chemie.uni-giessen.de</span></a></p><a class="moreInfoLink" href="/authored-by/Rohnke/Marcus">Search for more papers by this author</a></div></span></div>
         </div>
      </div>
   </div>
   <div class="epub-sections"><div class="epub-section"><span class="epub-state">First published: </span><span class="epub-date">22 January 2024</span></div>

href="#citedby-section">5</a></span></div></div><span class="openUrl"><a    <div class="abstract-group  metis-abstract">
      <section class="article-section article-section__abstract" lang="en" data-lang="en" lang-name="English" id="section-1-en">
         <h2 id="d63932384" class="article-section__header section__title main abstractlang_en main">Abstract</h2>
         <div class="article-section__content en main">
            
            <p>The anode/electrolyte interface behavior, and by extension, the overall cell performance of sodium-ion batteries is determined by a complex interaction of processes that occur at all components of the electrochemical cell across a wide range of size- and timescales. Single-scale studies may provide incomplete insights, as they cannot capture the full picture of this complex and intertwined behavior. Broad, multiscale studies are essential to elucidate these processes. Within this perspectives article, several analytical and theoretical techniques are introduced, and described how they can be combined to provide a more complete and comprehensive understanding of sodium-ion battery (SIB) performance throughout its lifetime, with a special focus on the interfaces of hard carbon anodes. These methods target various length- and time scales, ranging from micro to nano, from cell level to atomistic structures, and account for a broad spectrum of physical and (electro)chemical characteristics. Specifically, how mass spectrometric, microscopic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, thermodynamic, and physical methods can be employed to obtain the various types of information required to understand battery behavior will be explored. Ways are then discussed how these methods can be coupled together in order to elucidate the multiscale phenomena at the anode interface and develop a holistic understanding of their relationship to overall sodium-ion battery function.</p>
            </div>
      </section>
   </div>
   <div class="pb-dropzone" data-pb-dropzone="below-abstract-group"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div>
   
   <section class="article-section article-section__full">
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0010">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0010-title">1 Introduction</h2>
         
         <p>One of the primary challenges in transitioning from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources is the fluctuating availability of wind and solar energy; advanced energy storage technologies are needed to ensure a reliable power supply during production and consumption peaks. Therefore, secondary batteries are gaining importance not only in the automotive industry, but also for stationary storage of electrical energy at the grid scale.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0001" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0001_R_d63932372e790" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 1">1</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0003" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0003_R_d63932372e790" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 3 - Energy Environ. Sci.">3</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been at the forefront of energy storage technology since the early 1990s due to their relatively high energy density (260 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>), reasonable cost ($153 per kWh), and long lifespan.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0004" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0004_R_d63932372e799" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 4 - J. Power Sources">4</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0006_R_d63932372e799" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">6</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In spite of these impressive features, LIBs exhibit several significant shortcomings that hinder their widespread use for electric vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Two of the main constituting elements, lithium and cobalt, are relatively rare and unevenly distributed across the globe, which has created mining practices that are politically and ethically concerning.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0007" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0007_R_d63932372e804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 7 - Energy Environ. Sci.">7</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The scarcity of these metals, coupled with the high cost of the copper current collector, causes the overall LIB system to be too expensive and too rare for a full global transition to renewable energy, especially in developing countries. Additionally, the electrolyte species and cobalt-based cathode materials pose long-term toxicity and ecological concerns.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0008" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0008_R_d63932372e810" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 8 - Environ. Sci. Technol.">8</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) offer several significant advantages over LIBs regarding these challenges. Sodium is the 6<sup>th</sup> most abundant element on earth and is more evenly distributed throughout the globe.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0009" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0009_R_d63932372e819" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 9 - ACS Energy Lett.">9</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SIBs can be fabricated with cheaper aluminum as a current collector for both electrodes, rather than copper, and the problematic cobalt cathode components can be replaced by compounds based on less critical elements, such as manganese and iron. These factors correspond to a marked increase in safety and sustainability, and a substantial reduction in battery costs. The theoretical energy density of SIB technology, ≈150&nbsp;Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0009" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0009_R_d63932372e826" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 9 - ACS Energy Lett.">9</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> is lower than that of LIBs, and limits its application in portable devices and electric vehicles, where weight is a significant factor. This is less of an issue for stationery and grid-scale energy storage applications, where the gravimetric energy density is less of a concern and has a relatively low impact for grid-scale storage. This allows for SIBs to be a cost-effective alternative to LIBs as the primary energy storage technology for stationary applications.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0010" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0010_R_d63932372e832" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 10 - Adv. Energy Mater.">10</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0003" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0003_R_d63932372e832" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 3 - Energy Environ. Sci.">3</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The chemical similarities between Li<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> allowed for the application of knowledge and design strategies from LIBs to guide the initial development of SIBs. The complex battery phenomena that have been the subjects of decades of study for LIBs, such as reactivity, stability, and intercalation, can be used as a baseline of comparison for SIBs. Both systems implement similar electrode materials, the same solvents, and sodium/lithium analogues of the same conducting salts.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0011" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0011_R_d63932372e843" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 11">11</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0012" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0012_R_d63932372e843" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 12 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">12</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Still, in spite of these component and mechanistic similarities, SIBs exhibit many behavioral differences compared to LIBs in regards to stability and reactivity.</p>
         
         <p>Graphite has long been the standard anode material in LIBs, and provides a theoretical maximum storage capacity of 372 mAhg<sup>−1</sup> (LiC<sub>6</sub>). The Li<sup>+</sup> cation is able to easily intercalate between the graphene layers, however, bonding behavior of the Na<sup>+</sup> cation inhibits this behavior, leading to substantially diminished capacity (maximum NaC<sub>64</sub>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0013" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0013_R_d63932372e863" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 13 - J. Inorg. Nucl. Chem.">13</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0015" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0015_R_d63932372e863" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 15 - RSC Adv.">15</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Research for anode materials in SIBs has instead focused on hard carbon (HC), which has previously been investigated for use in LIBs, offering storage capacities of up to 350 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0007" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0007_R_d63932372e870" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 7 - Energy Environ. Sci.">7</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0016" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0016_R_d63932372e870" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - Sustainable Energy Fuels">16</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Some of the insights gained from graphite can be applied to HC, as both are carbon-based insertion structures with relatively similar chemistries. HC is mostly derived from renewable resources such as sugar, starch, cellulose, and bio-waste such as peanut shells and fruit peels. The microstructure of the initial feedstock is preserved, though, with a lower density.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0017_R_d63932372e876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">17</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0021" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0021_R_d63932372e876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 21 - Mater. Adv.">21</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This preservation causes significant problems with battery design, as every HC sample is different, and has significantly different effects on the cell performance and SEI formation.</p>
         
         <p>The carbon structure present in graphite, consisting of parallel graphene layers, is only found in HC in microscopic domains (40&nbsp;Å, 2-11 layers). HC is instead comprised of disordered carbon structures, such as non-planar fragments and deformed graphene-like layers, without long-range ordering of the graphitic domains. Covalent C─O─C bonds are formed between the layers at 900 °C and are considered the main cause of both non-graphitizability and hardness. This disordered microstructure causes HC to have an amorphous macrostructure, with pores and voids up to 500 nm in diameter, and surface areas that range from &lt;10 to &gt;100 m<sup>2</sup>g<sup>−1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0017_R_d63932372e888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">17</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0018_R_d63932372e888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Mater. Today">18</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0022" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0022_R_d63932372e888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 22 - Carbon">22</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0027" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0027_R_d63932372e888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 27 - J. Mater. Chem. A">27</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These pores and voids are responsible for the effective storage of Na<sup>+</sup>, but the exact storage mechanisms are complex and not yet fully understood.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0028_R_d63932372e896" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - ACS Energy Lett.">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The widespread success of LIBs is largely due to the selection of effective electrolyte and electrode materials. During the initial cycles in half- and full-cells, electrolyte species react with and deposit at the electrode surface, which leads to the formation of a stable anode–electrolyte interfacial layer known as the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0006_R_d63932372e903" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">6</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0016" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0016_R_d63932372e903" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - Sustainable Energy Fuels">16</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0029_R_d63932372e903" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">29</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The SEI layer protects the electrode surface from degradation while allowing facile ion transport, and is fundamentally important<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0030_R_d63932372e908" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Nat. Rev. Mater.">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for the effective function of a battery. A well-formed SEI must also passivate against further electrolyte decomposition; as a significant amount of the charge carriers are consumed during the formation process, and uncontrolled reactions diminish the capacity of the cell.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0018_R_d63932372e913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Mater. Today">18</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0029_R_d63932372e913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0031_R_d63932372e913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - Nano Energy">31</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0032_R_d63932372e913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - Prog. Energy">32</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This is a significant problem in SIBs; their SEIs are shown to be significantly less stable than their LIB counterparts, in spite of having very similar chemical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0033" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0033_R_d63932372e919" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 33 - ACS Energy Lett.">33</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0034" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0034_R_d63932372e919" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 34 - Adv. Energy Mater.">34</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The loss of reversible capacity, i.e., the trapping of sodium, is quantified by the initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), a measure comparing the first charge and discharge capacities. State-of-the-art SIBs, with capacities &gt;300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, have achieved ICE values of 95%.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0035_R_d63932372e926" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - Energy Storage Mater.">35</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0040_R_d63932372e926" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Beyond that, batteries require a coulombic efficiency (CE) of at least 99.96%<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0041" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0041_R_d63932372e932" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 41 - Joule">41</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to obtain suitable capacities after 500 cycles to be economically viable.</p>
         
         <p>The number of publications concerning SIBs has increased exponentially since the early 2000s and the number of publications focused on the SEI over HC electrodes has grown at a commensurate rate, as can be seen in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0001">1</a>. This shows firstly, the growing relevance of SIB technology in the global energy sector, and secondly, that the SEI is an integral part of the battery system. The abundance of research can be overwhelming, and the presence of vague sources and conflicting ideas can make it difficult to develop a clear, systemic, understanding of the SEI and anode interface in SIBs.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0001"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/dcd0d95f-b7b8-4450-9334-331e6d16d6fa/aenm202302830-fig-0001-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/dcd0d95f-b7b8-4450-9334-331e6d16d6fa/aenm202302830-fig-0001-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a9bd9b5e-cf64-418a-948e-da2398de1dce/aenm202302830-fig-0001-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/dcd0d95f-b7b8-4450-9334-331e6d16d6fa/aenm202302830-fig-0001-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 1<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0001&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Number of search results for the search items as listed in the legends at webofscience.com (31/05/2023). “SIB” stands for “Sodium-Ion Batteries” as full search item.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>With this perspective, we highlight the techniques and methods that are necessary for the investigation of the SEI on HC in SIBs. We couple this with a focus on the type of information that is gained from each method, and how different methods can be used in conjunction to obtain a clearer picture than either method provides on their own. Finally, we suggest the need for comprehensive multiscale studies to fully investigate and develop a deeper understanding of the formation and evolution of the SEI on HC electrodes in SIBs during electrochemical cycling. The effect of small changes in component properties on overall SIB performance necessitates that these multiscale studies must work in unison, using the same materials and cell preparations, in order to obtain clear and accurate information.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0020">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0020-title">2 Current State of Research</h2>
         
         <p>In a typical SIB, the anode (negative electrode) consists of HC with a mechanically stabilizing binder, such as polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0023_R_d63932372e975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Electrochim. Acta">23</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0044" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0044_R_d63932372e975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 44 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">44</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or carboxymethylcellulose (CMC),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0035_R_d63932372e980" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - Energy Storage Mater.">35</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0045_R_d63932372e980" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - J. Mater. Chem. A">45</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0046_R_d63932372e980" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">46</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and an electrically conductive substance such as carbon black. Aluminum is typically used as a current collector. The positive electrode consists of the cathode material (Prussian blue analogues,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0047" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0047_R_d63932372e985" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 47 - Chem. Commun.">47</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0048" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0048_R_d63932372e985" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 48 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">48</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyanionic composites,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0049" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0049_R_d63932372e991" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 49 - Adv. Mater.">49</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0050" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0050_R_d63932372e991" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 50 - Adv. Energy Mater.">50</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or layered oxides<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0051" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0051_R_d63932372e996" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 51 - Adv. Energy Mater.">51</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0052" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0052_R_d63932372e996" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 52 - Adv. Energy Mater.">52</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) coated onto the aluminum current collector. The electrodes are separated by a short-circuit-preventing separator and an electrolyte solution consisting of ether- or ester-based solvent(s), conductive salt, and additives. The properties and behavior of the initially formed SEI are influenced by many parameters of the battery but are most strongly impacted by the electrolyte chemistry and the electrode surface characteristics. The majority of SIB SEI research is therefore focused on either the properties of the HC anode surface, or on the electrolyte.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0053" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0053_R_d63932372e1002" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 53 - Small">53</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0054" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0054_R_d63932372e1002" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 54 - Nat. Energy">54</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The surface characteristics and ion insertion behavior of the HC anode have a significant effect on the properties of the SEI. Many studies are working to elucidate the complex storage behavior of Na<sup>+</sup> in HC, and there is still active debate about the exact mechanisms. The most accepted theory is known as the “3-step model” developed by Bommier et&nbsp;al. In this model, Na<sup>+</sup> is adsorbed at defect sites, intercalated between graphene sheets with larger spacing than in graphite, and ultimately accumulated in pores, resulting in a plateau region at higher capacity values.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0055_R_d63932372e1013" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - Nano Lett.">55</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Others argue that intercalation, not plating in pores, is represented by the plateau region and responsible for the majority of Na<sup>+</sup> storage.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0056" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0056_R_d63932372e1021" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 56 - Adv. Energy Mater.">56</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A challenge for comparing these studies is related to the different synthesis routes from different sources and with that the inconsistent nature of HC. Different initial feedstocks produce HC with substantially different material properties and electrochemical behavior. Significant differences also emerged in HCs made from different batches of the same type of feedstock.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0011" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0011_R_d63932372e1026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 11">11</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0057" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0057_R_d63932372e1026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 57 - Chem. Eng. J.">57</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0058" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0058_R_d63932372e1026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 58 - ChemSusChem">58</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This makes a consistent study of HC very difficult, as there is no well-established baseline to use as a point of reference.</p>
         
         <p>Bommier et&nbsp;al. also reported that the surface area accessible to adsorbed gas is proportional to the open porosity, and inversely proportional to the reversible capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0022" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0022_R_d63932372e1034" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 22 - Carbon">22</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors explained the negative impact of open porosity by considering the proportion of exposed carbon relative to the total mass of carbon used. The highest capacities were measured in samples with the lowest proportion of exposed carbon, and vice versa, highlighting the role of available surface area for SEI formation. Defect atoms serve as nucleation sites for SEI particle formation, which aligns with cathodic electrolyte degradation.</p>
         
         <p>Research is focused at engineering the HC electrode and surface design to maximize storage capacity and encourage favorable surface characteristics for SEI formation. The microstructure, surface area, and the number of defects and heteroatoms can be tailored by controlling the precursor, milling parameters, heating rate, and temperature. These methods aim to minimize the surface area of open pores while maximizing the volume of closed pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0018_R_d63932372e1042" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Mater. Today">18</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hierarchically-porous HC surfaces have been designed in order to create microchannels that promote rapid ion insertion, facile electrolyte transport, and favorable SEI formation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0059" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0059_R_d63932372e1047" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 59 - Rare Met.">59</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The electrolyte composition has a larger impact on the SEI than any other part of the battery, and many different chemistries are being explored. Ester- and ether-based solvents are most-commonly used, such as cyclic propylene carbonate (PC) and ethylene carbonate (EC), as well as linear dimethyl carbonate (DMC), ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (chemical structures shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0002">2</a>). Glymes and crown ethers are also being investigated for use in SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0060" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0060_R_d63932372e1060" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 60 - Nat. Commun.">60</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0062" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0062_R_d63932372e1060" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 62 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">62</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Preferred electrolyte properties include low viscosity, a wide electrochemical stability range, and high ionic conductivity. Ester-based solvents tend to produce thicker and less-uniform SEIs compared to ethers but are still preferred due to their lower viscosity and higher conductivity. Binary,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0044" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0044_R_d63932372e1065" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 44 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">44</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0063" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0063_R_d63932372e1065" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 63 - Waste Biomass Valorization">63</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or less frequently, ternary<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0064" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0064_R_d63932372e1071" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 64 - Energy Environ. Sci.">64</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0065" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0065_R_d63932372e1071" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - Electrochem. Commun.">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> mixtures of cyclic and linear esters are often used in order to further improve viscosity and transport. The thermal stability of the electrolyte must also correspond to the specific application. Excessive temperatures or improper charging of the cell can lead to solvent decomposition, gas formation, and irreversible cell damage.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0006_R_d63932372e1076" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">6</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0002"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/6922faae-cc88-44d1-b662-42fcb9b05b43/aenm202302830-fig-0002-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/6922faae-cc88-44d1-b662-42fcb9b05b43/aenm202302830-fig-0002-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/d53c1601-0a8d-4e72-986e-8a9b3d7f6799/aenm202302830-fig-0002-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/6922faae-cc88-44d1-b662-42fcb9b05b43/aenm202302830-fig-0002-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 2<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0002&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Chemical structures of typical electrolyte solvents used in SIBs.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>The conductive salts used in SIBs are typically sodium analogs of well-established salts used in LIBs (such as NaClO<sub>4</sub>, NaPF<sub>6</sub>, NaTFSI, shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0003">3</a>). The ionic conductivity and electrode (de)insertion behavior are strongly dependent on the interaction between the charge carrying cation and the anionic species. The mobility of the anions is considered quasi-stationary due to their larger radii compared to Na<sup>+</sup>, whereas the mobility of Na<sup>+</sup> ions is influenced by the “closed shell” interaction with the solvent.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0066_R_d63932372e1116" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - Adv. Mater.">66</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> NaClO<sub>4</sub> and NaPF<sub>6</sub> are currently the most promising electrolytes for SIBs, however, they pose some safety concerns, and other salts are being explored.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0006_R_d63932372e1126" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">6</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These alternative salts exhibit additional challenges; NaTFSI, for example, is corrosive and degrades the aluminum current collector, while other salts simply do not provide satisfactory performance, e.g., in terms of ionic conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0066_R_d63932372e1131" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - Adv. Mater.">66</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0067" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0067_R_d63932372e1131" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">67</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0003"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/e8eb0eaa-e8df-44ba-936b-23142796db9f/aenm202302830-fig-0003-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/e8eb0eaa-e8df-44ba-936b-23142796db9f/aenm202302830-fig-0003-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/8cdecc4d-8ec3-4ac4-a5e4-e7d62ab44797/aenm202302830-fig-0003-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/e8eb0eaa-e8df-44ba-936b-23142796db9f/aenm202302830-fig-0003-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 3<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0003&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Common conductive salts applied in SIBs.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>Much work is dedicated to gaining insights about the decomposition mechanisms and products of common solvents, salts, and additives, to understand the species that make up the SEI. The SEI typically consists of inorganic species, such as NaCl, NaF, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>O, NaOH,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0018_R_d63932372e1163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Mater. Today">18</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0025_R_d63932372e1163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">25</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e1163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0066_R_d63932372e1163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - Adv. Mater.">66</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0068_R_d63932372e1163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - Energy Storage Mater.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and organic species, such as Na-ethylene dicarbonate (NaEDC), and Na-ethylene glycol (NEG).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0043_R_d63932372e1169" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The exact composition and structure of the SEI varies depending on the specific system chemistry, and the composition and structural features are still not fully understood even for individual systems.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0069" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0069_R_d63932372e1174" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 69 - Batteries">69</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Electrolyte additives have been introduced as a possible way to stabilize against electrochemical decomposition and to selectively modify the SEI. Several studies have investigated fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as additive but have observed mixed results. FEC appears to improve the stability of the SEI<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0043_R_d63932372e1181" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to the degree that it remains intact even when the electrolyte is replaced with an additive-free solution.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0064" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0064_R_d63932372e1186" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 64 - Energy Environ. Sci.">64</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0070" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0070_R_d63932372e1186" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 70 - Adv. Mater.">70</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Others argue that FEC increases the polarizability and instability of the cell, and that the polarizability and instability of the cell costs outweighs the benefits of the stronger SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0071" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0071_R_d63932372e1191" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 71 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">71</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Different effects of FEC are observed in full-cells versus half-cells for the same chemistry, which highlights the interconnectedness of all of the cell components.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0072" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0072_R_d63932372e1197" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 72 - Nanoscale">72</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Other additives such as difluoro ethylene carbonate (DFEC), ethylene sulfite (ES), and vinylene carbonate (VC) have been excluded from further investigations due to inadequate stability or reduced cell capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0025_R_d63932372e1202" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">25</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The significant influence of the electrolyte solution on the physical and chemical properties of the SEI is evident from their distinct compositions. SIMS and XPS measurements on SEIs formed in different electrolytes reveal different components. Komaba et&nbsp;al. conducted SIMS measurements on SEIs formed under otherwise identical conditions, with the only difference being the cation (Na<sup>+</sup>/Li<sup>+</sup>). They attributed the same role of a protective passivation layer to both SEIs, with the sodium-based SEI containing a higher proportion of inorganic species due to its thinner nature.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0025_R_d63932372e1213" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">25</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Consistent with this finding, Carboni et&nbsp;al. identified Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> as the main component in the SEI formed using an electrolyte consisting of NaTFSI in PC with the additive FEC. Pan et&nbsp;al. predominantly found sodium ethylene dicarbonate (SEDC) in the SEI formed using NaPF<sub>6</sub> in the solvent mixture of EC:DEC (1:1).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0073_R_d63932372e1225" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Oltean et&nbsp;al. also reported a significantly thinner sodium-based SEI from EC:DEC (1:1.5), where the proportion of inorganic compounds also outweighed that of a lithium-based SEI from EC:DMC (1:1), which mainly consists of organic compounds. Similar results were previously obtained by Komaba et&nbsp;al. for SEIs from PC electrolyte for both Na- and Li-ion battery cells.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0025_R_d63932372e1230" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">25</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0074_R_d63932372e1230" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - Chem. Mater.">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hirsh et&nbsp;al. identified the main constituents of a SEI formed in PC (1 M NaPF<sub>6</sub>) as Na-alkyl carbonates, polyesters, hydroxides, NaF, and Na<sub>2</sub>O,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0068_R_d63932372e1240" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - Energy Storage Mater.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which aligns well with similar results from Huang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0066_R_d63932372e1245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - Adv. Mater.">66</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and Carboni et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e1251" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> All these observed compositions are chemically similar to those found in LIBs. It must be considered, however, that SEI components of SIBs are more soluble and less stable than their lithium analogues. The solubility of SEI components significantly influences the chemical composition and physical properties beyond the first cycle. NaF and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> are 20–50 times more soluble in common ester solvents than LiF and Li<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, respectively. This difference is likely to be even more pronounced for organic SEI components and one of the primary reasons for the observed SEI stability difference between LIBs and SIBs. As the SEI dissolves over time, recurrent electrolyte degradation reactions take place at the thinner and poorly passivated electrode interface, leading to irreversible capacity loss via unchecked consumption of Na<sup>+</sup>. The exact mechanism of this dissolution and degradation is still unclear, and is the subject of current investigations.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0006_R_d63932372e1267" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">6</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0033" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0033_R_d63932372e1267" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 33 - ACS Energy Lett.">33</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0075_R_d63932372e1267" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Batteries Supercaps">75</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0076" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0076_R_d63932372e1267" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 76 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">76</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Other studies work to develop an understanding of the SEI on a more fundamental level, such as determining the formation and degradation mechanisms, and the specific that properties correspond to improved cell performance. There is a loose consensus on the thinness of the SEI in ester-based SIBs, although absolute values vary due to the absence of binder or Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>C signals in XPS measurements. Values ranging from 10 to 50&nbsp;nm have been reported.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e1278" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0073_R_d63932372e1278" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hirsh et&nbsp;al. used CV measurements to argue that the low values of ICE depend on the presence of partially reversibly bound sodium components in the SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0068_R_d63932372e1283" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - Energy Storage Mater.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Rangom et&nbsp;al. observed different cycling behaviors in cells subjected to different first charge and discharge rates.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0077" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0077_R_d63932372e1289" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 77 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">77</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This difference was determined to be caused by changes in the initial formation of the SEI, however, XPS measurements did not reveal any chemical differences in the formed SEIs. They attributed the different cell responses regarding electronic and ionic impedance, as well as capacitance to variations in SEI thickness, density, and microstructure. They also observed an inverse relationship between charge rate and volumetric expansion of the SEI, such that the thinnest and most stable SEI with the lowest impedance was formed at the highest tested charge rate. Bommier et&nbsp;al. proposed the hypothesis of a SEI growing towards the anode, which they argued was not responsible for capacity loss. They attributed the capacity reduction to the degradation of the electrolyte at the sodium-metal counter electrode and the passivation of the counter electrode itself.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0078" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0078_R_d63932372e1294" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">78</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Similarly, Cresce et&nbsp;al. determined a reduced role of solvated Na<sup>+</sup> ions in SEI formation in SIB.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0079" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0079_R_d63932372e1302" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 79 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">79</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>There are many scientific papers published every year describing the SEI in SIBs. Most of which only focus on single, isolated, parts of the battery, missing the complex and interconnected influence of the entire cell on the phenomena that occur on the anode surface. Moreover, these studies are carried out with different HC samples and cell setups, which restricts comparison between studies and generates conflicting ideas. A comprehensive understanding of the reactions involved in the formation and evolution of the SEI during cell assembly, cycling and storage must be developed.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0018_R_d63932372e1309" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Mater. Today">18</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0031_R_d63932372e1309" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - Nano Energy">31</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0039" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0039_R_d63932372e1309" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 39 - Electrochim. Acta">39</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>In this perspective, we present experimental and computational methods, which, from our point of view, are essential for the development of a complete understanding of SIB performance. We seek to emphasize that, while these methods are invaluable on their own, unified, multiscale studies, with consistent materials, are needed in order to provide a clear and comprehensive picture of the processes that occur inside SIBs.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0030">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0030-title">3 Analytical Methods</h2>
         
         <p>In this section, we will discuss several analytical methods used for battery research, loosely in order of scale, beginning with full-scale and operando techniques.</p>
         
         <p>The individual analytical methods used to study SIBs are largely similar to those used for LIBs. With the exception of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance and X-ray based techniques, which will be discussed in more detail in their respective sections, very few changes need to be made to the system setups and operation. The largest difference between SIBs and LIBs in regard to analytical methods is the relative benefit of integrating multiple techniques into single studies.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0080" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0080_R_d63932372e1326" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 80 - Front. Chem.">80</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The robust and consistent behavior of LIBs allows for clear and accurate studies using individual isolated techniques. In contrast, the sensitivity of SIB cell behavior to small changes in the cell, and to the influence of processes at many different size- and timescales, means that single techniques often do not provide a clear understanding of the cell properties and phenomena. Integrated multiscale approaches consisting of multiple techniques are required to elucidate these behaviors.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0040">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0040-title">3.1 Differential/Online Electrochemical Mass Spectrometry (DEMS/OEMS)</h3>
            
            <p>DEMS and OEMS both describe in situ/operando methods that use mass spectrometry to analyze the gases that evolve during electrochemical processes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0081" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0081_R_d63932372e1339" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 81 - Adv. Energy Mater.">81</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0083_R_d63932372e1339" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - J. Power Sources">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> DEMS and OEMS are often used interchangeably, but have differ slightly in regard to setup and data collection. The main difference of the two is that OEMS does not allow for instantaneous (differential) gas detection when applying a voltage or current, but instead has a delay in time. Previous studies in the area of batteries have focused on SEI formation and cell degradation studies, primarily on LIBs, and only recently on SIB/HC chemistries.</p>
            
            <p>DEMS can be realized by probing the gas in direct proximity of the electrode by attaching a gas-permeable membrane directly to a porous electrode. For aqueous electrolytes, a hydrophobic membrane is usable for this purpose. For organic electrolytes such membranes are not applicable, because the organic solvents in batteries can diffuse through the membrane and drain from the cell, which alters the behavior of the battery. Other sampling methods were developed for such batteries in order to counteract this problem, such as probing the gases using valves to extract samples from a head space above the battery. A continuously operated OEMS for batteries may also be achieved by allowing the evolving gas to enter a bypassing stream that contains a carrier gas. A general schematic of the OEMS setup is shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0004">4</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0004"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/3c08864c-8a08-421b-b750-4af85395f586/aenm202302830-fig-0004-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/3c08864c-8a08-421b-b750-4af85395f586/aenm202302830-fig-0004-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/dfa443ab-7555-4135-b6b1-d367b7316b2d/aenm202302830-fig-0004-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/3c08864c-8a08-421b-b750-4af85395f586/aenm202302830-fig-0004-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 4<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0004&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic of a generalized OEMS setup with bypass containing a carrier gas. Not all setups include a sampling system.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>All setups consist of a potentiostat for electrochemical cycling/monitoring, often combined with EIS measurements, and sometimes thermal controls. The gas flow in OEMS systems with bypass is generally realized by an argon gas carrier stream which transports the product gas stream from the battery cell to the mass spectrometer. The stream is regulated by valves in order to prevent significant drying of the cell during periodic probing.</p>
            
            <p>OEMS setups have been reported in literature to investigate different-sized battery cells. Experimental small-scale setups for coin-sized cells have been developed by academical facilities, as well as commercial suppliers, for the investigation of materials at coin cell size. Other groups have reported inserting a gas draining system into commercial cell formats like cylindrical and pouch cells.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0084" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0084_R_d63932372e1376" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 84 - J. Power Sources">84</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0085" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0085_R_d63932372e1376" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 85">85</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The recorded intensities of the mass-to-charge ratios <i>m</i>/<i>z</i> can be associated with the spectra of the product gasses. However, most mass spectrometers do not have sufficient mass resolving power to differentiate between species with similar masses. One example for this is the common formation gases C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub> and CO when EC electrolytes are used. In this case, other <i>m</i>/<i>z</i>-values of the molecular fragments are used for the identification and quantification of these species.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0082_R_d63932372e1397" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - J. Mater. Res.">82</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Still, the unambiguous identification of unique decomposition fragments of the product gases for quantification remains challenging.</p>
            
            <p>In mass spectrometry, quantification of the gas amounts is often coupled to complex calibration protocols, which must be performed frequently. Not all setups fully transport all evolving gasses into the mass spectrometer, furthermore, the ion current signal of the MS may drift over time. The overall number of species tracked in a given test, including both whole molecules and fragments, is limited due to sampling time constraints. Internal references of the carrier gas and calibration gases, with regulated species concentrations and flows, are used for precise quantification.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0083_R_d63932372e1405" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - J. Power Sources">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This quantification protocol must be performed for every product species observed. This raises general maintenance and calibration expense for mass spectrometry.</p>
            
            <p>The analysis and identification of the reaction mechanisms leading to the gas formation can be challenging, as the only information obtained is the composition of the product gases. Gases like CO and CO<sub>2</sub> can be produced from solvent decomposition at the electrodes, or also from decomposition of the salt, electrode, or separator materials. Modifying the experimental design can help to distinguish between the different sources, but when electrodes are varied, new interactions with other components are also observed.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0082_R_d63932372e1415" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - J. Mater. Res.">82</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>OEMS measurements of sodium|graphite half cells by Goktas et&nbsp;al. using ether electrolytes have shown gas evolution during equilibration and the first cycle.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0086_R_d63932372e1422" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Adv. Energy Mater.">86</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Equilibration before cycling showed development of CO, which is attributed to reactions with the sodium electrode. During the first cycle, CO, CH<sub>4</sub>, H<sub>2</sub>, C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> and C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub> were observed. However, in TEM measurements no SEI was found, indicating that the gas did not stem from solvent decomposition to typical SEI products.</p>
            
            <p>The gas development is therefore attributed to electrode surface impurities. The electrolyte is assumed not to form an SEI at all, leading to the assumption of an SEI-free battery in ether systems.</p>
            
            <p>Zhang et&nbsp;al. investigated the gas evolution in SIBs with different anode, cathode, and electrolyte chemistries using half- and full-cell setups with carbonate electrolyte.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0087" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0087_R_d63932372e1445" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 87 - Energy Storage Mater.">87</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Their results support the hypotheses that there are multiple degradation mechanisms of electrolyte and additives. They also identified how Na-metal electrodes and different types of cathode material impacts gas evolution. Further studies also examined cathode gassing in layered oxides and Prussian blue analogues.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0082_R_d63932372e1450" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - J. Mater. Res.">82</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0088" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0088_R_d63932372e1450" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 88 - J. Power Sources">88</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>In our own studies, the formation of HC//sodium-vanadium-phosphate (NVP) cells with 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC:PC (1:1) electrolyte has been investigated. Preliminary results, shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0005">5</a>, indicate that most reactions only take place in the first cycle, whereas hydrogen production continues in the subsequent cycles.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0005"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/51d48ad8-9876-4119-8dc3-9e5a47d5b398/aenm202302830-fig-0005-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/51d48ad8-9876-4119-8dc3-9e5a47d5b398/aenm202302830-fig-0005-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/4636759f-2115-4756-9c34-48b8692ea4dc/aenm202302830-fig-0005-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/51d48ad8-9876-4119-8dc3-9e5a47d5b398/aenm202302830-fig-0005-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 5<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0005&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Example of an OEMS measurement. Baseline subtracted. Small peaks can be attributed to measurement artefacts. The measurement was conducted with a cell chemistry of HC|NVP 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC:PC (1:1). Hydrogen development can be observed during the first and second cycle, while ethene at <i>m/z</i> 26 can only be observed in the first cycle. Since <i>m/z</i> 28 can indicate both ethene and CO, it is not clear whether CO is formed or the ethene is causing the peak.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>In conclusion, OEMS enables essential insights into gas-producing degradation reactions at HC/electrolyte interfaces of SIBs; gas evolution can be quantified during operando measurements and correlated to operating conditions, as well as electrode and electrolyte design. More OEMS studies are needed in order to determine the degradation rates and mechanisms of the electrolyte and electrode interface in SIBs quantitatively and uniquely.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0050">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0050-title">3.2 Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS)</h3>
