            <p>Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy techniques are an integral part of many cycling protocols to expand on the information that is gained from (mostly galvanostatic) cycling experiments in battery cell tests. EIS offers a noninvasive means to study electrode processes and derive (in theory) individual contributions of the cell resistance. The aim of the technique is to pinpoint bottlenecks in the charge-transfer and mass transport processes during the cell reaction. However, the complexity to work out such parameters unambiguously in a typical thin-layer battery setup (coin or pouch-cell formats) is often underestimated.</p>
            
            <p>EIS probes an electrochemical system using a periodic voltage perturbation signal with a small amplitude over a range of frequencies. EIS is thus an alternating current (AC) method, in which the system is supposed to oscillate around an equilibrium state, inducing reversible, but no irreversible, changes. The potential changes display linear current–overpotential relationships (<i>i</i>–<i>ƞ</i>)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0089" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0089_R_d63932372e1512" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 89">89</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for amplitudes smaller than a few tens of mV (typically &lt;20 mV). The application of current perturbations is also possible. However, the amplitude in this case is specific to the capacity of the system. EIS can be extended to study the characteristic nonlinear <i>i</i>–<i>ƞ</i> behavior at electrode/electrolyte interfaces by applying larger amplitudes (in case of E-perturbations). This is referred to as nonlinear frequency response analysis and is highly surface sensitive. It may be used, e.g., to distinguish between SEI- and plating-related aging of Li-ion batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0090" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0090_R_d63932372e1522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 90 - Curr. Opin. Electrochem.">90</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Impedance (<i>Z</i>) is the opposition to alternating current and the result of the combined effect of resistance and reactance in an electrical circuit. Resistance (<i>R</i>) represents the dissipation of heat (energy loss) and is frequency independent. Reactance (<i>X)</i> is a frequency-dependent response in AC circuits from inductors and capacitors. For capacitors, reactance stores energy and returns it into the circuit a quarter-cycle later, causing both a shift in phase angle and (frequency dependent) change in amplitude with respect to the input signal. The impedance, <i>Z</i>(<i>ω</i>), is defined as the vector sum of real (<i>Z</i>’) and imaginary (<i>Z</i>’’) contributions of the circuit components. Impedances of series or parallel circuit configurations follow Kirchhoff's current law. Because the three properties, resistance, capacitance <i>C</i>, and inductance <i>L</i>, respond differently to alternating currents, impedance spectroscopy enables conclusions about the components of electrical circuits, based on changes in amplitude and phase shifts with frequency.</p>
            
            <p>EIS measurements are often paired with models in order to help extract battery parameters and estimate the state of battery (degradation):<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0091" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0091_R_d63932372e1551" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 91 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">91</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Equivalent circuit models attempt to translate the response from an electrochemical system into known electrical circuit components. A simple example is provided in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0006">6a</a>, for a hexacyanoferrate redox couple in aqueous solution at a Pt electrode. The electrode process can be expressed in a so-called Randles circuit (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0006">6a</a>, inset). In this representation, Faradaic processes are expressed as a resistor (charge-transfer, <i>R</i><sub>ct</sub>), non-Faradaic processes, like the electrochemical double layer, are expressed as capacitors (e.g. <i>C</i><sub>dl</sub>) and diffusion processes, such as solid-state diffusion in an active material and mass-transport in the electrolyte in batteries, are represented with the so-called Warburg impedance (<i>W</i> or <i>Z</i><sub>W</sub>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0092_R_d63932372e1578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Meas. Sci. Au">92</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hence, there can be clear physical connections between basic elements and processes. More complex and accurate models are being developed and will be discussed in Section&nbsp;<a class="sectionLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202302830-sec-0160">4</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0006"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0c1b3217-43f4-42bf-bc73-151ac0e5fdaf/aenm202302830-fig-0006-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/0c1b3217-43f4-42bf-bc73-151ac0e5fdaf/aenm202302830-fig-0006-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a80580bc-de91-4ccb-91b8-b33ac2e93b4e/aenm202302830-fig-0006-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0c1b3217-43f4-42bf-bc73-151ac0e5fdaf/aenm202302830-fig-0006-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 6<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0006&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">EIS spectrum of hexacyanoferrate redox couple in 10 × 10<sup>−3</sup> <span class="smallCaps">m</span> K<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> aqueous solution at a Pt-electrode. Experimental data is shown as empty circles; fitted data as solid line with black dots. a) Nyquist plot with inset of electrode process and rationalization of equivalent circuit model. b) corresponding Bode plots for |<i>Z</i>| and phase angle versus frequency.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>We wish to emphasize some fundamental details about Nyquist plots (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0006">6a</a>), as they are often displayed incorrectly in literature. In these plots, <i>Z</i>’ and <i>Z</i>’’ of Z(<i>ω</i>) are plotted in the complex-plane for each frequency. The distance from the origin of the complex plane to the data point is the absolute value of <i>Z</i>(<i>ω</i>). Note that for a semicircle to appear as a semicircle, the axes in Nyquist plots must be plotted orthonormal (not only the tick labels but the actual plot width and height). Though this information is trivial, it is frequently ignored in literature. Nyquist plots contain frequency information indirectly, as each data point represents the impedance at a given frequency. However, this complicates the comparison of different samples, as different data series can be easily shifted in the frequency domain while displaying similar impedance values. Therefore, it is good practice to label characteristic frequencies in a Nyquist plot or provide the corresponding Bode plots. The Bode representation offers a means to plot |<i>Z</i>|, <i>Z</i>’, <i>Z</i>’’, or the phase angle <i>φ</i>, as a function of frequency (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0006">6b</a>) and is a useful addition when presenting EIS data. Bode plots are more suited to demonstrate that simulated impedance spectra fit the experimental data not only in magnitude, but also fall in the correct frequency domain.</p>
            
            <p>The strength of EIS lies in the possibility to separate electrode processes on different time scales, ranging from a few mHz to several MHz. For example, charge redistribution in the electrochemical double layer occurs on faster time scale than electrode reactions which, in turn, occur faster than associated mass transport processes. EIS is applied to answer a large variety of scientific questions in battery research. On a material research level, EIS is used to investigate aging of electrode materials, formation and resistivity of surface layers, and questions related to the charge-transfer process. As studies are mostly done on composite electrodes, EIS spectra also contain information about electrode porosity. The complexity of EIS spectra in 2-electrode systems is high, as spectra are superpositions of signatures from both the negative and positive electrodes (and the electrolyte), especially if porous electrodes are studied. Although the use of half-cell configurations simplifies the interpretation, metallic counter electrodes, such as Li foil, age during storage and cycling, and thus display different signatures in EIS spectra depending on their cycling history. This problem is amplified in post-Li batteries that use more reactive alkali metals, like Na or K.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0093" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0093_R_d63932372e1648" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 93 - Electrochim. Acta">93</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In case of the latter, contributions from the working electrode may be masked or obscured by the high impedance of the counter electrode. 3-electrode setups help to single out contributions of cell components but require reliable reference electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0094" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0094_R_d63932372e1653" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 94 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">94</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The choice of cell setup has a profound impact on the acquired data. For example, electrode misalignment, and even the symmetry and position of the reference electrode with respect to working and counter electrode, influence the resulting EIS spectra.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0095" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0095_R_d63932372e1660" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 95 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">95</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0097" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0097_R_d63932372e1660" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 97 - Electrochem. Commun.">97</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In many battery-related studies, interpretations of EIS spectra are carried out by comparing spectra of different samples. Because of the complexity of porous electrodes, commonly used equivalent circuit models, such as the Randles circuit, are insufficient to describe all electrode processes, as well as charge and mass transport in particle networks. Electrical circuits are not unique, and therefore the goodness-of-fit to acquired data does not validate models unambiguously. In this context, the Gaberšček group coined the term “arbitrary (equivalent) circuit”<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0098_R_d63932372e1665" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0099" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0099_R_d63932372e1665" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 99 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">99</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for series circuits with multiple Voigt-elements (parallel circuits with a capacitor in one branch and a resistor in the other), as these models may carry little-to-no physical meaning. Physics-based models, on the other hand, can provide a sound phenomenological basis for derived parameters, but are often not straightforward to implement in EIS fitting software for occasional EIS users. In the analysis of EIS spectra, it is a challenge that processes, i.e., their relaxation times, may overlap strongly, and thus not appear as individual semicircles in the spectrum, but rather create a merged (superimposed) arc that closely resemble semicircles. In fact, composite electrodes often show features originating from electrode porosity that appear as distorted semicircles that might be misinterpreted as electrode processes<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0100" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0100_R_d63932372e1670" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 100 - Electrochim. Acta">100</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0007">7</a>). Such ambiguous spectra can only be resolved by changing measurement conditions, for example by varying the temperature (change charge-transfer kinetics), changing the electrolyte concentration (change mass transport properties/electrolyte conductivity),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0101" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0101_R_d63932372e1681" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 101 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">101</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> applying different stack pressure (reduce contact resistance)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0102_R_d63932372e1687" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - Electrochem. Solid-State Lett.">102</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or replacing the electrolyte salt with redox-inactive compounds<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0103" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0103_R_d63932372e1692" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 103 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">103</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> in order to “turn-off,” mask or overexaggerate certain processes.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0007"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/6299ca87-c946-45e0-aab4-48e6821ed84d/aenm202302830-fig-0007-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/6299ca87-c946-45e0-aab4-48e6821ed84d/aenm202302830-fig-0007-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/d12a6960-dcd0-454c-9e6d-80d1bf749955/aenm202302830-fig-0007-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/6299ca87-c946-45e0-aab4-48e6821ed84d/aenm202302830-fig-0007-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 7<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0007&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Simulated impedance spectra of 3D recreations of different pore geometries. Reproduced under terms of the CC-BY license.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0100" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0100_R_d63932372e1717" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 100 - Electrochim. Acta">100</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2017, Cooper et&nbsp;al. Elsevier Ltd.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Hence, even though setting up EIS measurements is easy, acquiring reliable data and going through the process of understanding the individual features and the dominating parameters in EIS spectra requires more time and effort than many reports appear to be willing to invest.</p>
            
            <p>In two recent works, Linsenmann et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0094" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0094_R_d63932372e1727" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 94 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">94</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0104" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0104_R_d63932372e1727" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 104 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">104</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> first developed a microreference electrode based on partly sodiated tin wire in order to investigate electrode pore resistance in pristine HC//Na 3-electrode half-cells, from which tortuosity values can be derived. The authors used the 3-electrode setup to track the evolution of cell impedance with state-of-charge (SOC) on the first cycle, i.e., at different stages of SEI formation and sodiation of the HC electrode. To account for porosity effects, the authors fitted their data with a transmission line model. Compared to a corresponding HC//Li half-cell, the electrode resistance was 4–5 times higher and at 100% SOC (end of charge) the charge-transfer resistance, <i>R</i><sub>ct</sub>, derived from fitted spectra was found to be about 10 times larger for the Na half-cell than for the Li half-cell. The example demonstrates the potential of EIS in the evaluation of cell characteristics and as a non-invasive technique to analyse SOC, state-of-health, but also useful physicochemical properties of the electrochemical system.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0060">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0060-title">3.3 Operando Stress Measurements Using Substrate Curvature</h3>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">Almost all physical and chemical processes that occur in a solid alter its mechanical stresses. Stress measurements can therefore be used to investigate the fundamental mechanisms that occur in the material. The substrate curvature technique allows to measure stresses in thin layers and at interfaces with extremely high resolution. Today this technique is used in many fields for quantifying stresses and ensuring reliability of devices, for example, in the microelectronics industry (wafer curvature). In the early 20<sup>th</sup> century Stoney<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0105" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0105_R_d63932372e1747" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 105 - Proc. R. Soc. London, Ser. A">105</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used the curvature of a substrate to determine stresses that are associated with electroplating. This allowed him to develop the following relation:

               <div class="inline-equation" id="aenm202302830-disp-0001"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE-->
                     <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/74cc1970-c7df-4c5e-ad10-7ce738c57b93/aenm202302830-math-0001.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0001" display="block" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0001.png">
                        <semantics>
                           <mrow>
                              <msub>
                                 <mi>σ</mi>
                                 <mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi>
                              </msub>
                              <mo linebreak="badbreak">≈</mo>
                              <mfrac>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mi>E</mi>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <msubsup>
                                       <mi>h</mi>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msubsup>
                                 </mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mn>6</mn>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mi>h</mi>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators="">
                                       <mrow>
                                          <mn>1</mn>
                                          <mo>−</mo>
                                          <msub>
                                             <mi>ν</mi>
                                             <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                          </msub>
                                       </mrow>
                                    </mfenced>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mfrac>
                              <mfrac>
                                 <mn>1</mn>
                                 <mi>R</mi>
                              </mfrac>
                           </mrow>
                           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">$$\begin{equation}{\sigma }_{\mathrm{f}} \approx \frac{{{E}_{\mathrm{S}}h_{\mathrm{S}}^2}}{{6{h}_{\mathrm{f}}\left( {1 - {\nu }_{\mathrm{S}}} \right)}}\frac{1}{R}\end{equation}$$</annotation>
                        </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(1)</span></div>
            </div>
            
            <p>For films that are much thinner than their substrate (ℎ<sub>f</sub> « ℎ<sub>S</sub>) the stress <i>σ</i><sub>f</sub> is inversely proportional to the radius of curvature <i>R</i>. The processes under investigation cause equibiaxial stresses in the film and deform the film-substrate-laminate into the shape of a shell of a sphere. Knowledge of the mechanical properties of the film is not required since the proportionality constant only contains elastic mechanical parameters of the ceramic substrate (<i>E</i><sub>S</sub>, ν<sub>S</sub>). The stress-thickness product <i>σ</i><sub>f</sub> ⋅ ℎ<sub>f</sub> is the force acting per unit length at the film–substrate interface. It can be used instead of <i>σ</i><sub>f</sub> when <i>h</i><sub>f</sub> is not known or when surface or interface mechanisms are of interest.</p>
            
            <p>Nowadays, the curvature is measured by reflected laser beam(s). The beams hit a cantilever distant from the clamp that holds the film inside the test cell. The curvature of the cantilever between the laser spots can be determined, by tracking the position of the reflected laser beams with a pixel detector and using a simple geometry (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0008">8</a>). The presence of an electrolyte and its refractive index affects the laser deflection. The non-linearity in the law of refraction can complicate these measurements. If the setup can be designed in a way that the outgoing laser beam is approximately perpendicular to the window of the test cell, the deflection is linearly dependent on the refractive index.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0106_R_d63932372e1832" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Power Sources">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Equation&nbsp;<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202302830-disp-0001" title="Link to equation">1</a> is only valid for thin films, for thicker electrodes, deviations must be expected, and the mechanical properties of the film affect the radius of curvature. This is a concern for electrodes of real batteries, in particular, and assumptions need to be made how the curvature can be related to stress and/or volume changes of the electrode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0106_R_d63932372e1841" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Power Sources">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0008"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/584ffd49-4fcf-46b3-9a9c-8aa59069baf2/aenm202302830-fig-0008-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/584ffd49-4fcf-46b3-9a9c-8aa59069baf2/aenm202302830-fig-0008-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/20799eda-84d2-4a94-acc6-362bcaca8442/aenm202302830-fig-0008-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/584ffd49-4fcf-46b3-9a9c-8aa59069baf2/aenm202302830-fig-0008-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 8<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0008&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">An electrochemical test cell inside a substrate curvature setup.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>In battery research, substrate curvature has been used to monitor stresses during electrode operation. A correlation of electrochemical and mechanical data as obtained by substrate curvature is then used to investigate fundamental electrochemical processes. On the one hand, the measured electrode potential of an electrode (relative to the counter electrode) originates from its interface with the electrolyte, i.e., it can be considered as an information from the electrode surface. On the other hand, the mechanical stress originates from both, the interface, and the volume of the electrode. For electrodes with finite thickness, the volume expansion and contraction typically dominate, so that stress data is complementary to the simultaneously recorded potential of the electrode.</p>
            
            <p>With its high sensitivity, the substrate curvature technique is able to observe the volume expansion of zero-strain electrodes with high resolution<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0106_R_d63932372e1870" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Power Sources">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and can detect processes at interfaces, for example, the deposition of fractions of monolayers of atoms.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0107" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0107_R_d63932372e1875" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 107 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">107</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Detailed reviews of the technique<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0108" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0108_R_d63932372e1880" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 108">108</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and its application to batteries<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0109" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0109_R_d63932372e1886" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 109 - Prog. Mater. Sci.">109</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0110" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0110_R_d63932372e1886" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 110 - J. Mater. Chem. A">110</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been published. The technique has been mainly used for anode materials, but applications for cathode materials can also be found in the literature. So far, the focus was clearly based on lithium-ion batteries and only limited data exists on post-lithium systems.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0111" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0111_R_d63932372e1891" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 111 - Energy Technol.">111</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0112" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0112_R_d63932372e1891" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 112 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">112</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Thoroughly investigated lithium-based anode materials include&nbsp;lithium titanate (LTO),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0106_R_d63932372e1897" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Power Sources">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> silicon,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0113" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0113_R_d63932372e1902" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 113 - Appl. Phys. Lett.">113</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> germanium,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0114" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0114_R_d63932372e1907" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 114 - J. Power Sources">114</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and aluminum.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0115" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0115_R_d63932372e1913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 115 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">115</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Research on cathodes includes layered oxides for lithium-ion batteries<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0116_R_d63932372e1918" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - ECS Electrochem. Lett.">116</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the olivine FePO<sub>4</sub>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0111" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0111_R_d63932372e1926" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 111 - Energy Technol.">111</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The latter describes a special case; in this work, lithium was exchanged by sodium in the same electrode and the change in the mechanical stresses during cycling were used to infer reaction pathways, including phase transformations, which differ significantly for both insertion ions.</p>
            
            <p><b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0009">9</a> shows the electrochemical potential versus Na<sup>+</sup>/Na and the measured stress-thickness product of a characteristic cycle of a cantilever that was spray coated with HC. While the electrochemical potential is almost symmetrical between charge and discharge, large differences are apparent in the stress-thickness curves. Stresses at the plateau voltage are more compressive during sodium insertion than during extraction. This indicates that the storage process is less symmetrical than expected according to electrochemical data. Within a cycle, irreversible mechanical work is performed in the HC. During extraction, the stress is less dependent on the sodium content (plateau in stress thickness); it remains constant while the electrode changes its volume. This suggests that force-controlled processes are active. This bears resemblance with plastic deformation where the generation and motion of crystalline defects cause changes in shape or volume. Additional investigation of the temperature and rate dependence is required and will help to better understand the sodium storage mechanism of HC.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0009"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/02eb4b9c-1cd1-4fae-a51e-83eb4815a138/aenm202302830-fig-0009-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/02eb4b9c-1cd1-4fae-a51e-83eb4815a138/aenm202302830-fig-0009-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/873d6c66-5780-47c4-bf70-ca759b0dd583/aenm202302830-fig-0009-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/02eb4b9c-1cd1-4fae-a51e-83eb4815a138/aenm202302830-fig-0009-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 9<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0009&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Stress-thickness and electrochemical potential of the 5<sup>th</sup> cycle of hard carbon (spray coated on a cantilever) cycled in 1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC/PC 1:1 with 10 mA g<sup>−1</sup>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
         </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0070">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0070-title">3.4 Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (ToF-SIMS)</h3>
            
            <p>ToF-SIMS is a surface sensitive mass spectrometric method for the layered 3D analysis of solid materials<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0117" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0117_R_d63932372e1977" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 117">117</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0118" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0118_R_d63932372e1977" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 118">118</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> that is able to obtain information about the lateral- and depth distribution of elements and fragments of chemical compounds. In the often-used dual beam approach, a liquid metal ion gun (LMIG, <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0010">10a</a>) is used to ballistically impact a surface with a low current, highly focused, pulsed primary ion (PI) beam. This impact causes molecular fragmentation and the emission of secondary ions (SI) of both polarities from the surface. Either cations or anions are collected via an electrical field and transferred in a mass analyzer. In state of the art time-of-flight mass analyzers (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0010">10b</a>), the fragments are separated and distinguished with a mass resolution of up to <i>m</i>/Δ<i>m</i> &gt; 28,000, while the lateral resolution of the scanning PI beam goes down to &lt;50 nm. Secondary electrons are also produced during SI generation and can be used for electron microscopy with a lateral resolution &lt;40 nm.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0010"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/b1354e9e-8f44-4177-9369-325ce28c0cc1/aenm202302830-fig-0010-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/b1354e9e-8f44-4177-9369-325ce28c0cc1/aenm202302830-fig-0010-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a1963c1e-dee0-455d-946b-cf9b2e749a15/aenm202302830-fig-0010-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/b1354e9e-8f44-4177-9369-325ce28c0cc1/aenm202302830-fig-0010-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 10<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0010&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematics of a ToF-SIMS measurement setup with a) the LMIG, b) the ToF-analyzer and c) the sputter gun. For each pixel a mass spectrum (i) is obtained. Images (ii) can be formed by highly focusing the PI beam. Alternated usage of the LMIG and the sputter gun leads to profiles (iii) showing the depth distribution of the detected fragments.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Regions below the surface can be cleaved for analysis by applying a high current beam from an additional low energetic sputter gun (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0010">10c</a>), which etches into the sample at micron-range depths. Charge accumulation on the surfaces of electrically insulating materials is avoided by using a low energy electron gun. A focused ion beam (FIB) milling option for cross-sectional imaging and tomography is also applicable.</p>
            
            <p>For pulsed PI sources, surface roughness impairs the mass resolution of the time-of-flight analyzer, as fragments emerging from different heights exhibit slightly different flight times, increasing the width of corresponding peaks. Ultrahigh vacuum conditions are essential to impede collisions between the pulsed/secondary ions and gaseous particles. Volatile and highly amorphic, “soft” samples may be analyzed under cryogenic conditions, for which a liquid nitrogen-cooled sample stage can be provided.</p>
            
            <p>Information gathered from this method consists of mass spectra for pixels (2D) or voxels (3D). The former is usually displayed as mass spectra or 2D images showing the lateral distribution of chemical fragments. The latter is mostly displayed as graphs, called depth profiles, or as 3D distribution cuboids that take the lateral information of each layer into consideration.</p>
            
            <p>A major advantage of the technique is its superior sensitivity due to the high transmission of SIs in combination with single ion counting detectors, which allows for detection limits up to ppb range. Usage of larger PI species or clusters from a gas cluster ion beam (GCIB), such as Ar<sub>1500</sub><sup>+</sup>, allows for the ionization of large fragments of weights up to 12,000 u, which tends to be a limitation for organic molecules. Organic SIs of this size require an orbitrap analyzer with a resolution of <i>m</i>/Δ<i>m</i> &gt; 240,000 @ <i>m</i>/<i>z</i> 200 possibly in combination with tandem mass spectrometry to be distinguished unambiguously.</p>
            
            <p>The area of analysis can be extended beyond the reach of the PI grid (usually about 500×500 µm<sup>2</sup>), by moving the sample stage. This effectively takes multiple measurements in a grid, at the borders of previous measurements, and digitally stitches several measurement fields together.</p>
            
            <p>A disadvantage of this method is its high fragmentation rate for molecules during the collision cascade with the PIs. This complicates the data analysis. In this connection multivariate analysis methods allow for the identification of significant variables, thereby reducing the complexity of the mass spectrometric information. PCA (principal component analysis) or MCR (multivariate curve resolution) can be used to show differences between samples in terms of mass spectra and within depth profiles. More detailed information about the application of ToF-SIMS in battery research, its advantages, limitations and best practice is given in a recently published article by Lombardo et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0119" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0119_R_d63932372e2048" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 119 - J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A">119</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Understanding interfacial behavior and the interphase formation process is crucial for the development of battery-cells and energy storage devices. The SEIs in SIBs and LIBs have thicknesses in the order of 10 nm, and require surface sensitive equipment, like ToF-SIMS, to be analyzed, as the layers are too thin to be easily examined with other methods.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0068_R_d63932372e2055" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - Energy Storage Mater.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>A depth profile MCR analysis of the SEI formed in a SIB cell after 20 cycles on HC is shown exemplarily in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0011">11</a>. The relative intensity and fluence of the various fragment profiles reveals a clear layered structure of the SEI. Sublayers of sodium oxide and hydroxide are formed on top of a halide salt layer, which is covering the bulk material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0046_R_d63932372e2067" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">46</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Some fluorine signals show broader in-depth distributions, hence its signature in the bulk. Chlorine oxides on the surface may be residues of the NaClO<sub>4</sub> conducting salt, while the outermost organic layer consists of decomposition products of the electrolyte solvent, as shown by XPS measurements.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0068_R_d63932372e2075" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - Energy Storage Mater.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0011"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/48628230-d780-4a03-826c-f513e16b2317/aenm202302830-fig-0011-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/48628230-d780-4a03-826c-f513e16b2317/aenm202302830-fig-0011-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/bc6e0a17-d71a-46ae-961b-3d0c180b8ee4/aenm202302830-fig-0011-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/48628230-d780-4a03-826c-f513e16b2317/aenm202302830-fig-0011-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 11<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0011&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Top: 5 factor MCR-Analysis of a ToF-SIMS depth profile of the SEI on a Hard Carbon electrode from a sodium-ion battery. Bottom: graphical depiction of the results above.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The groups of Komaba<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0025_R_d63932372e2102" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">25</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and Lust<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0120" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0120_R_d63932372e2107" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 120 - Electrochim. Acta">120</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have conducted ToF-SIMS measurements on the SEI in SIBs at HC anodes. The interaction and reaction products between the solvent and a sodium salt, such as NaClO<sub>4</sub> or NaPF<sub>6</sub>, exhibit different behavior compared to their corresponding lithium salts. The difference is that the SEI in SIBs consists mainly of inorganic salts, including: Na<sub>2</sub>O, NaOH, NaCl, NaF, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>PO<i><sub>y</sub></i>. The SEI in LIBs, on the other hand, consists primarily of organic species.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0080">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0080-title">3.5 X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS)</h3>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">XPS is a surface-sensitive characterization technique that is able to study the composition, chemical bonding, and electronic structure of surfaces and interfaces.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0121" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0121_R_d63932372e2138" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 121">121</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Inside a photoelectron spectrometer, typically operated at ultra-high vacuum, a (monochromatic) X-ray beam irradiates the surface of a sample with photons. If the incident photon energy (ℎ𝜈) is larger than the electron binding energy <i>E</i><sub>B</sub>, the impact causes the emission of photoelectrons (schematically depicted in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0012">12</a>) from core and valence levels of near-surface atoms to the vacuum level. Any excess energy is transferred to the electrons as kinetic energy <i>E</i><sub>K</sub>. <i>E</i><sub>K</sub> is measured using an electron analyzer and allows for the calculation of the electrons’ binding energy using Equation&nbsp;<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202302830-disp-0002" title="Link to equation">2</a>, where <i>ϕ</i> is the spectrometer work function.

               <div class="inline-equation" id="aenm202302830-disp-0002"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE-->
                     <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/99851b31-324e-48fc-9bab-3569747a9e95/aenm202302830-math-0002.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0002" display="block" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0002.png">
                        <semantics>
                           <mrow>
                              <msub>
                                 <mi>E</mi>
                                 <mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi>
                              </msub>
                              <mo linebreak="badbreak">=</mo>
                              <mspace width="0.33em"></mspace>
                              <mi>h</mi>
                              <mi>ν</mi>
                              <mo linebreak="goodbreak">−</mo>
                              <msub>
                                 <mi>E</mi>
                                 <mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi>
                              </msub>
                              <mo linebreak="goodbreak">−</mo>
                              <mi>ϕ</mi>
                           </mrow>
                           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">$$\begin{equation}{E}_{\mathrm{B}} = \ h\nu - {E}_{\mathrm{K}} - \phi \end{equation}$$</annotation>
                        </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(2)</span></div>
            </div>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0012"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/38eddae7-a590-4bd4-9821-4354d8a76112/aenm202302830-fig-0012-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/38eddae7-a590-4bd4-9821-4354d8a76112/aenm202302830-fig-0012-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/79bed46f-7ddb-49f6-a8cd-5986f61f2aff/aenm202302830-fig-0012-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/38eddae7-a590-4bd4-9821-4354d8a76112/aenm202302830-fig-0012-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 12<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0012&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Schematic representation of the photoemission process from a cycled battery electrode with SEI. b,c) Show the approximate intensity <i>I</i> distribution for the resulting photoelectron signal from such an idealized layered sample in dependence of the inelastic mean free path <i>λ</i> of the photoelectrons in the material.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The photoelectron binding energy is specific for each element, and thus allows for the qualitative determination of the elementary composition. Moreover, the binding energy depends on the oxidation state and bonding environment of the atoms or molecules; changes in binding energy resulting from these environments are known as chemical shifts.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0121" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0121_R_d63932372e2216" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 121">121</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The peak intensity, i.e., the area under the peak, is directly proportional to the concentration of atoms of a given element and provides quantitative information about the surface chemistry.</p>
            
            <p>The surface sensitivity of XPS stems from the strong interaction between photoelectrons and the sample.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0122" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0122_R_d63932372e2224" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 122">122</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Only electrons that leave the sample without losing energy (i.e., without inelastic scattering) contribute to the characteristic photoemission peaks. The probability for an electron to escape the sample surface without energy loss decreases exponentially as a function of the electron emission pathway and its inelastic mean free path <i>λ</i> (see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0012">12c</a>). Thus, most of the signal stems from near-surface regions (see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0012">12b</a>); the information depth is typically set to 3 <i>λ</i>, as this corresponds to 95% of the signal intensity for vertical electron emission. <i>λ</i> is dependent on both the composition of the sample material and the incident photoelectron kinetic energy. This energy dependence can be harnessed to achieve essentially nondestructive depth profiling by using synchrotrons to tune the incoming photon energy in order to change the kinetic energy of the electrons. Furthermore, the surface sensitivity can be enhanced using smaller electron take-off angles (grazing emission). However, the obtained data is always a weighted average of the entire probed volume, with the largest fraction of the signal intensity stemming from the region nearest to the surface. Evaluation of the depth-dependent composition of the near-surface region therefore requires an extensive data set that is rarely available. Quantitative analysis of atomic concentrations in the near-surface region, with the help of atomic sensitivity (ASF) factors,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0121" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0121_R_d63932372e2242" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 121">121</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> is even more cumbersome because of the different kinetic energies, and thus different <i>λ</i> values, of the respective photoelectrons. For a more detailed review of photoelectron spectroscopy in battery research, the reader is referred to ref. [<span><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0123" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0123_R_d63932372e2248" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 123 - J. Mater. Chem. A">123</a></span>]</p>
            
            <p>XPS has become an indispensable tool in battery and SEI research; research groups use laboratory and synchrotron-based XPS to characterize SEI layers in Li-ion batteries based on the methods outlined in the seminal work from Peled and Edström.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0124" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0124_R_d63932372e2255" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 124 - J. Power Sources">124</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0126" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0126_R_d63932372e2255" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 126 - Electrochim. Acta">126</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This is partly due to surface sensitivity. With λ in the order of 3–4 nm for soft and carbonaceous materials,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0118" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0118_R_d63932372e2260" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 118">118</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> using an Al K<sub>α</sub> X-ray source, the information depth in XPS is of the order of 10&nbsp;nm, and thus is ideally suited to study surface and interfacial layers in batteries, which typically have thicknesses in the same range. The thickness of the SEI layer can be estimated via bulk signal attenuation by tuning the excitation energy in such a way that a signal from the underlying bulk electrode can still be detected.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0126" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0126_R_d63932372e2268" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 126 - Electrochim. Acta">126</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The chemical shifts due to changes in oxidation state and bonding environment allow for detailed analysis of SEI components, as well as the effects of sodiation. Relative peak shifts between the surface layer and the bulk electrode material provide further information on the electronic properties of the interface.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0127" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0127_R_d63932372e2276" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - J. Phys. Chem. Lett.">127</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0128" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0128_R_d63932372e2276" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 128 - J. Phys. Chem. C">128</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The chemical evaluation is reasonably straightforward for simple binary compounds, such as NaF or well-known molecular species, but can be challenging for more complex species, as exact binding energies of the various decomposition products in the SEI are mostly unknown. A detailed analysis should also consider the fixed ratio of the different elements in a given molecular moiety, as given by its stoichiometry. As a result, because of the complexity of the evaluation, detailed analyses of the molecular composition of the SEI, also including the decomposition products, are highly challenging and scarce. Furthermore, they are at best semi-quantitative, assuming a homogeneous lateral composition and neglecting local variations therein. In summary, a complete quantitative elemental and molecular analysis of the SEI layer and its depth dependent composition, even though theoretically feasible, is essentially impossible at present and would require a huge data set. Combination with AI based evaluation schemes may also become helpful in future.</p>
            
            <p>More information on the molecular composition of the SEI may be obtained by comparing experimental binding energies with calculated ones, using the states of all elements within a potential decomposition product.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0129" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0129_R_d63932372e2284" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 129 - Batteries Supercaps">129</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0130_R_d63932372e2284" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Despite the large overlap in some signals, e.g., because of similar functional groups, other elemental peaks may show distinct differences, which eventually may allow to discriminate between different decomposition products.</p>
            
            <p>In HC-based Na-ion batteries, XPS has mainly contributed to the understanding of SEI formation, composition, and stability. Early work by Dahbi et&nbsp;al. describes the initial SEI after one cycle of HC sodiation and desodiation in various electrolytes using soft and hard XPS. They observed the best electrochemical performance for HC cycled in 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> in PC with FEC, and attributed this to the formation of a thinner SEI layer.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0131" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0131_R_d63932372e2296" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 131 - ChemElectroChem">131</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Carboni et&nbsp;al. followed the SEI evolution during initial cycling on glucose-derived HC in 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaTFSI in PC with 3% FEC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e2304" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> They found that the organic–inorganic hybrid SEI evolved in composition and thickness upon cycling, but stabilized after approximately 10 cycles. Using XPS, the authors also showed incomplete desodiation of HC, as residual Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>C was observed in the desodiated state. This irreversible Na trapping was postulated as an additional cause for large irreversible capacity losses in HC-based Na-ion batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0042_R_d63932372e2312" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - ChemElectroChem">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Fondard et&nbsp;al. studied the SEI on HC electrodes after long-term cycling using two excitation energies for depth-profiling and observed the best electrochemical performance for systems with a NaPF<sub>6</sub> and FEC-containing electrolyte. They were then able to correlate the improved performance to a SEI rich in SEDC and NaF, while poor electrochemical performance was associated with electrodes with either low NaF or high Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> contents in the SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0043_R_d63932372e2325" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The Passerini group studied the dependence of the SEI composition and thickness on the electrolyte using a consistent HC electrode,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0132" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0132_R_d63932372e2331" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 132 - Nano Energy">132</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and also on the initial HC electrode surface composition and morphology using three different HC synthesis protocols.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0075_R_d63932372e2336" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Batteries Supercaps">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors reported a decrease in organic SEI species on sodiated HC depending on the electrolyte salt anion in the order: NaPF<sub>6</sub> &gt; NaClO<sub>4</sub> &gt; NaTFSI &gt; NaFTFSI &gt; NaFSI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0132" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0132_R_d63932372e2346" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 132 - Nano Energy">132</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The type of HC, on the other hand, had no detectable effect on the type of species present in the SEI, but did proportionally influence the concentrations of different components relative to the concentrations of oxidized species present on the pristine HC electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0075_R_d63932372e2351" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Batteries Supercaps">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Model studies performed on idealized, contamination-free and binder-free HC thin films, prepared by spray deposition,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0133" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0133_R_d63932372e2358" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 133 - Batteries Supercaps">133</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated that under ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) conditions at room temperature, vapor-deposited Na dissolves chemically, almost completely into clean HC (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0013">13</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0028_R_d63932372e2368" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - ACS Energy Lett.">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This underlines the facile insertion of Na in HC and corroborates theoretical predictions. In contrast, for the same amount of Na (2-3 monolayer equivalent) deposited on clean graphite at similar conditions (HOPG, Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0013">13</a>), dissolution is inhibited, and metallic Na films are formed (F. Buchner, R. J. Behm, unpublished results). This is indicated by the Na 1s peak at 1072.0 eV in combination with the specific plasmon loss features indicated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0013">13</a>. Furthermore, similar studies on the interaction of a presodiated HC film with 4–5 monolayer equivalents of the ionic liquid 1-butyl-1-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (BMP-TFSI) revealed that upon vapor deposition of the ionic liquid, Na is extracted from the near-surface regions and reacts with the ionic liquid (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0013">13</a>). The driving force for this purely chemical reactive extraction process is the energy gain upon reactive interaction between the extracted Na and the adsorbed ionic liquid. This chemical reaction can be considered as a part of the initial SEI formation in Na-ion batteries. Overall, the interaction between Na and BMP-TFSI closely resembles earlier findings for Li intercalated in HOPG.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0134" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0134_R_d63932372e2383" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 134 - J. Phys. Chem. C">134</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0013"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/e93ecda3-f14b-4fce-8255-2a8878963c22/aenm202302830-fig-0013-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/e93ecda3-f14b-4fce-8255-2a8878963c22/aenm202302830-fig-0013-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/259edfc2-3511-42e7-8429-afc4dc5c8f70/aenm202302830-fig-0013-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/e93ecda3-f14b-4fce-8255-2a8878963c22/aenm202302830-fig-0013-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 13<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0013&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Na 1s spectra of clean HOPG and a hard carbon film (black dots), after vapor deposition of similar amounts of Na on HOPG (blue dots) and on the hard carbon film (gray dots) under ultrahigh vacuum conditions, and upon further deposition of 4–5 monolayer equivalents of the ionic liquid BMP-TFSI (orange dots).</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Many studies compare and draw parallels between similar Na-ion and Li-ion systems,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0075_R_d63932372e2410" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Batteries Supercaps">75</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0132" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0132_R_d63932372e2410" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 132 - Nano Energy">132</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> while other works seek to elucidate the significant differences between the two monovalent battery chemistries. Photoelectron spectroscopy was used to prove,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0033" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0033_R_d63932372e2415" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 33 - ACS Energy Lett.">33</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> understand, and help mitigate,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0135_R_d63932372e2420" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> self-discharge behavior in Na-ion batteries due to SEI dissolution. Additionally, work on model Li<sub>4</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> electrodes for Na<sup>+</sup> insertion with either Na or activated carbon counter electrodes has demonstrated that XPS is able to determine the reaction products from the Na metal counter electrode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0136" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0136_R_d63932372e2435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 136 - ChemSusChem">136</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0090">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0090-title">3.6 Focused Ion Beam/Scanning Electron Microscopy (FIB/SEM) Tomography</h3>
            
            <p>Tomographic imaging using either X-ray computed tomography (CT), or FIB/SEM tomography of battery electrodes contributes to the understanding of the impact of 3D micro- and nanostructures on the overall performance of batteries. In addition, degradation processes within the electrode material associated with structural changes can be visualized in 3D through reconstruction of data sets.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0137_R_d63932372e2448" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Johnson Matthey Technol. Rev.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>FIB/SEM is a well-established technique, initially used for TEM lamella preparation and for maskless prototyping of micro- and nanostructures.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0138" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0138_R_d63932372e2455" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 138 - J. Microsc.">138</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0139" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0139_R_d63932372e2455" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 139">139</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A dual beam microscope comprises an ion beam column and an electron column which are usually mounted at an angle of 52–55° having their focal point at the specimen surface. Equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and/or electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) detectors, element mappings and information on crystalline structures are obtained. To date, commercial instruments are predominantly equipped with a liquid metal ion source (LMIS) using gallium due to its low melting point of 29.8 °C, low volatility, low vapor pressure, long lifetime, and good stability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0140" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0140_R_d63932372e2460" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 140 - MRS Bull.">140</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> E.g., at 30&nbsp;keV, gallium ion beams with 5 to 10&nbsp;nm focal spots and picoampere currents can be achieved. Given the inherent high kinetic energy of the focused Ga<sup>+</sup> ion beam, elastic and inelastic collisions result in a cascade of interactions, such as local ablation/sputtering processes, dislocations and vacancy formation, backscattered ions, ion implantation and generation of secondary electrons.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0141" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0141_R_d63932372e2468" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 141">141</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The sputtering process allows cross-sectioning and site-specific preparation of samples for subsequent SEM imaging (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0014">14</a>). By utilizing a sequence of sputtering and imaging steps, quantitative 3D reconstructions can be obtained. Although, FIB/SEM tomography can achieve smaller voxel sizes and hence higher resolution compared to X-ray CT, FIB/SEM tomography is a destructive method and Ga<sup>+</sup> ion implantation is an inherent problem leading to contamination and undesired doping of the investigated material. Within the last decade, FIB systems using liquid metal alloy ion sources and more recently with plasma sources (Xe, Ar, N, O) have been introduced, which allow for large-scale FIB/SEM tomography, by enhanced removal rates. Microscopes using gas field ion sources, e.g., He ions, provide larger depth of field and smaller beam diameters due to their shorter wavelength compared to electrons. Therefore, its superior resolution is mainly used for imaging, since its sputtering rate is significantly lower compared to the Ga<sup>+</sup> ions.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0141" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0141_R_d63932372e2483" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 141">141</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In comparison to Ga<sup>+</sup> ion milling, novel plasma focused ion beams (PFIB) enable sectioning of larger volumes with edge lengths &gt;100 µm.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0142" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0142_R_d63932372e2490" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 142 - J. Power Sources">142</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0143" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0143_R_d63932372e2490" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 143 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">143</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Implantation effects are reduced, as Xe is not enriched and detected at grain or phase boundaries, compared to Ga ions, which can i.e. accumulate along grain boundaries in aluminium.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0144" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0144_R_d63932372e2496" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 144 - J. Microsc.">144</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0014"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/16d109f8-0937-40b1-b3da-32e89c66e1f0/aenm202302830-fig-0014-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/16d109f8-0937-40b1-b3da-32e89c66e1f0/aenm202302830-fig-0014-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/08de122b-54e6-40fa-9639-a186d6648862/aenm202302830-fig-0014-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/16d109f8-0937-40b1-b3da-32e89c66e1f0/aenm202302830-fig-0014-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 14<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0014&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Schematic of focused ion beam/scanning electron microscopy tomography. b) Serial of stacked SEM slices of a hard carbon composite anode illustrating the consecutive slicing process for 3D reconstruction.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>X-ray CT<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0145" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0145_R_d63932372e2522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 145 - Mater. Today Adv.">145</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> usually provides information on features at the micrometer scale, such as large pore channels. Transmission electron (TEM) tomography<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0146" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0146_R_d63932372e2527" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - Acc. Chem. Res.">146</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> excels in the sub-10 nm resolution regime, enabling detailed imaging of nanosized specimens, but is limited in the overall size that can be investigated.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0147" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0147_R_d63932372e2532" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 147 - Catal. Today">147</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> FIB/SEM tomography can bridge the nanoscale to microscale domain with spatial resolutions ranging from a few to hundreds of nanometers. As depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0014">14</a>, volumes with edge lengths up to tens of micrometers<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0148" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0148_R_d63932372e2541" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 148">148</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> can be sliced with a slice width as small as several nanometers while recording a SEM image of the exposed cross-sections with resolution down to 1 nm.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0149" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0149_R_d63932372e2546" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149">149</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Tomography is an essential characterization tool for battery electrodes that plays a crucial role in identifying microstructural features, analyzing coating quality, evaluating the homogeneity of material distribution, but also enabling the visualization and identification of surface defects, grain boundaries, and changes in interfacial structures. This information is pivotal for understanding the electrode's structural stability, degradation mechanisms, effect of tortuosity and their impact on overall battery performance. In combination with EDS, the elemental distribution is obtained, providing information on segregation, diffusion and transformation of active species during electrochemical processes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0150" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0150_R_d63932372e2553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 150 - Chem. Geol.">150</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> FIB/SEM instruments equipped with EBSD give insights on grain orientations and grain architectures.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0151" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0151_R_d63932372e2558" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 151 - J. Power Sources">151</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Sample preparation is a key step in FIB/SEM tomography, particularly if porous composite materials are studied. Porosity may lead to undesirable artifacts such as shine-through effects<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0152" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0152_R_d63932372e2566" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 152 - Ultramicroscopy">152</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> due to pores, which are transparent for the electron beam. Filling the pore space of the electrode sample with materials like silicone resin minimizes redeposition and shine-through artifacts and enhances the grayscale contrast between individual electrode components. In addition, poor contrast between binder, conductive carbon and active electrode material and beam damage can be minimized by embedding the composite material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0153" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0153_R_d63932372e2571" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 153 - Electrochem. Commun.">153</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This enhanced contrast is crucial for accurately setting threshold values when reconstructing the data sets.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0154_R_d63932372e2576" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - J.
