Power Sources">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Staining procedures of organic components like active material<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0155" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0155_R_d63932372e2582" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 155 - J. Power Sources">155</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or binders<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0156" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0156_R_d63932372e2587" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 156 - J. Power Sources">156</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> with osmium tetroxide (OsO<sub>4</sub>) further enhance the contrast.</p>
            
            <p>3D reconstruction of FIB/SEM tomography data requires aligning and segmentation of the recorded 2D images. Alignment of the images is achieved by correlating shared features or fiducial markers, correcting for distortions, rotations, and translations. A challenge in 3D reconstructions is the determination of the threshold value for the segmentation of the images required to achieve accurate datasets. Recently, there has been a growing interest in the application of segmentation algorithms in combination with machine learning in order to increase the reliability of the segmented data sets, for instance, the pore volumes of highly porous systems, which is frequently underestimated.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0152" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0152_R_d63932372e2597" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 152 - Ultramicroscopy">152</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0157" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0157_R_d63932372e2597" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 157 - J. Power Sources">157</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0159" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0159_R_d63932372e2597" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 159 - Mater. Charact.">159</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This enables an enhanced semantic segmentation and subsequent classification of multiple phases within the FIB/SEM dataset, improving the overall quality of the results.</p>
            
            <p>FIB/SEM tomography provides access to information about the microstructural properties of anode and cathode materials.&nbsp;It is frequently used to visualize mechanical degradation phenomena, such as cracking, voiding, disconnecting, and fragmentation. Such investigations have primarily focused on cathode materials for LIBs, e.g., for layered oxides,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0160" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0160_R_d63932372e2605" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 160 - J. Power Sources">160</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0161" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0161_R_d63932372e2605" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 161 - J. Mater. Chem. A">161</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> iron phosphate,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0162" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0162_R_d63932372e2610" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 162 - J. Power Sources">162</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and graphite anodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0163" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0163_R_d63932372e2615" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 163 - J. Power Sources">163</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0164" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0164_R_d63932372e2615" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 164 - Micron">164</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The importance of volume fractions and distribution of the carbon binder domains (CBD) within cathode composite electrodes has been emphasized and studied by FIB/SEM tomography in order to correctly evaluate the electrolyte transport into the electrode structure. It has been shown that a heterogeneous tortuosity may lead to inhomogeneous charge/discharge states and degradation of the active material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0165" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0165_R_d63932372e2623" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 165 - Microsc. Microanal.">165</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Further, the CBD influences the overall pore phase,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0166" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0166_R_d63932372e2628" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 166 - J. Power Sources">166</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> agglomeration of particles, and active surface area,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0167" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0167_R_d63932372e2633" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 167 - J. Power Sources">167</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as well as blocks local surface reactions and impedes lithium redistribution.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0168" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0168_R_d63932372e2639" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 168 - Electrochim. Acta">168</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The obtained datasets are used as input for different approaches of computational modeling of electrode structures and their corresponding transport processes. For instance, effective electronic and ionic conductivities of nickel manganese cobalt oxides (NMC)-based electrodes can be estimated,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0169" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0169_R_d63932372e2644" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 169 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">169</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> by generating virtual models of real cathode structures, which overcome simplifications and lead to more realistic simulations.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0170" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0170_R_d63932372e2650" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 170 - Energy Technol.">170</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>FIB/SEM tomography has also been employed to characterize Si anodes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0171" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0171_R_d63932372e2657" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 171 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">171</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0174_R_d63932372e2657" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - J. Power Sources">174</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> metal–air batteries,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0175" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0175_R_d63932372e2662" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 175 - J. Power Sources">175</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0177" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0177_R_d63932372e2662" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 177 - Acta Mater.">177</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> solid-state batteries,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0178" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0178_R_d63932372e2667" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 178 - Chem. Mater.">178</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0180_R_d63932372e2667" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Environ. Mater.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and SEI layers.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0168" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0168_R_d63932372e2673" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 168 - Electrochim. Acta">168</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0171" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0171_R_d63932372e2673" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 171 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">171</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0172" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0172_R_d63932372e2673" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 172 - Sci. Bull.">172</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0181" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0181_R_d63932372e2673" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 181 - J. Power Sources">181</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Significant changes of pore space, volume expansion, and interconnectivity of the active material of a Si-based anode during the cycling process were visualized by FIB/SEM tomography, and revealed the almost complete saturation of the electrode's pore network by the SEI products.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0171" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0171_R_d63932372e2678" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 171 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">171</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It has been observed that the formation of the SEI effectively hinders the fragmentation of silicon anodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0172" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0172_R_d63932372e2684" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 172 - Sci. Bull.">172</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The visualization of structural changes and degradation of organic porphyrin-based Li-ion battery electrodes could be shown by FIB/SEM 3D reconstruction, and wavelength-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (WDX).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0155" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0155_R_d63932372e2689" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 155 - J. Power Sources">155</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The analysis of complex microstructures in NASICON-structured Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP), a potential cathode material for sodium-ion batteries, revealed the presence of continuous nano channels inside the NVP microspheres.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0182" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0182_R_d63932372e2703" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 182 - Energy Storage Mater.">182</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Similar investigations on post-Li materials have been the subject of only very few FIB/SEM studies.</p>
            
            <p>Porous organic, carbon-based electrodes are the preferred materials for supercapacitors and batteries due to their high energy-to-weight ratio, surface area, conductivity, and micro/nanoporous structure.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0183" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0183_R_d63932372e2711" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 183 - Adv. Mater. Sci. Eng.">183</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> FIB/SEM tomography and quantitative 3D reconstruction has been used to investigate mesoporous and porous carbon-based electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0184" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0184_R_d63932372e2716" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 184 - J. Power Sources">184</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hard carbon, which is the preferred anode material for SIBs, has not yet been characterized via FIB/SEM tomography. Only very recently, Tratnik et&nbsp;al. attempted to visualize SEI formation on hard carbon via FIB/SEM cross-sectioning, where a dense surface SEI was found.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0185" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0185_R_d63932372e2721" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 185 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">185</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> We have employed FIB/SEM to generate the first 3D reconstruction of an individual hard carbon particle and its pore space, shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0015">15</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0015"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/2916cb33-5796-4579-b5b1-6ffd5b04a7e9/aenm202302830-fig-0015-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/2916cb33-5796-4579-b5b1-6ffd5b04a7e9/aenm202302830-fig-0015-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/3d439a06-79c9-42bd-9a4b-17189c5006c6/aenm202302830-fig-0015-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/2916cb33-5796-4579-b5b1-6ffd5b04a7e9/aenm202302830-fig-0015-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 15<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0015&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) 3D reconstruction of a single hard carbon particle (green) and its pore space (red). b) Visualization of the pore space within the hard carbon particle.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
         </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0100">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0100-title">3.7 Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM)</h3>
            
            <p>Scanning probe microscopy (SPM) techniques, pioneered in the 1980s,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0186" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0186_R_d63932372e2761" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 186 - Appl. Phys. Lett.">186</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have significantly contributed to the visualization and understanding of nano- and microscale phenomena, and have recently gained interest for the study of interfacial phenomena at rechargeable battery electrodes. Many different techniques are included under the SPM “umbrella,” such as scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), electrochemical (ec-STM), atomic force microscopy (AFM) and AFM-derived techniques like ec-AFM and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM), scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM), scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) and hybrid SPM techniques (e.g., AFM-SECM, SICM-SECM) The common characteristic of these methods is that local physical or (electro)chemical interactions between the probe, e.g., AFM tip, and micro- or nano-sized electrode or nanopipette are recorded (see <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0016">16</a>). SPM techniques give access to nanoscale and microscale information on, e.g., surface properties and processes, based on the local physical or (electro)chemical interactions with the probe across as it scans the sample surface. SPM instruments can gain high-resolution information on interfaces and formed interphases in solution, allowing in situ and operando studies at the electrode/electrolyte interface during charging and discharging.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0016"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/f4b9a3d9-cceb-4ba1-8b58-bfab1e67d863/aenm202302830-fig-0016-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/f4b9a3d9-cceb-4ba1-8b58-bfab1e67d863/aenm202302830-fig-0016-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/163ff23c-8cb1-421c-9971-8131b0a0407b/aenm202302830-fig-0016-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/f4b9a3d9-cceb-4ba1-8b58-bfab1e67d863/aenm202302830-fig-0016-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 16<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0016&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Overview of selected S(E)PM techniques being utilized in battery research.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>SPM techniques are not as well-established in battery research as other characterization methods, but have recently risen in popularity because they are able to simultaneously obtain several characteristics of the cell, including: surface morphology, ionic fluxes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0187" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0187_R_d63932372e2793" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 187 - JACS Au">187</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> electrochemical properties, electrical conductivity,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0188" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0188_R_d63932372e2798" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 188 - J. Power Sources">188</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and nanomechanical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0189_R_d63932372e2803" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ChemElectroChem">189</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0190_R_d63932372e2803" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Nano Energy">190</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Some SPM techniques, like STM, are only used on model systems, and scarcely for in situ studies with real electrode materials.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0191" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0191_R_d63932372e2809" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 191 - J. Chem. Phys.">191</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To date, SPM studies in battery research are primarily focused on Li-ion batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0190_R_d63932372e2814" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Nano Energy">190</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0192" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0192_R_d63932372e2814" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 192 - Adv. Mater.">192</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0194" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0194_R_d63932372e2814" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 194 - Annu. Rev. Anal. Chem.">194</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A significant advantage of SPM compared to well-established electrochemical techniques is the insight into heterogeneity regarding nanomechanical, electrochemical, and electrical properties, which may originate from formed interphases. The rate performance of rechargeable batteries is predominantly constrained by the electrical conductivity of the anode and cathode materials and the ionic conductivity of the interfacial layers; this highlights the importance of correlating electrochemical data with material properties, such as conductance and Young's modulus, in order to elucidate local inhomogeneities. Whereas AFM-related techniques primarily provide physical information, scanning electrochemical probe microscopy (SEPM) techniques like SECM can provide information about charge transfer kinetics,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0195" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0195_R_d63932372e2820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 195 - Anal. Chim. Acta">195</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> double-layer capacitance,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0196" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0196_R_d63932372e2825" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 196 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">196</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> ion transport, diffusion, and local degradation,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0197" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0197_R_d63932372e2830" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 197 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">197</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> all of which are essential for battery performance. The crucial role of the SEI in facilitating the transport of ions while passivating electrons can be studied with SEPM techniques. Among the SPM techniques, AFM, ec-AFM,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0198_R_d63932372e2836" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - Sci. Rep.">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> electrochemical strain microscopy (ESM),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0199" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0199_R_d63932372e2841" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 199 - Nat. Nanotechnol.">199</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> quantitative nanomechanical AFM (QNM-AFM), and AFM force spectroscopy<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0200" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0200_R_d63932372e2846" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 200 - Nano Lett.">200</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0202_R_d63932372e2846" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - Nano Lett.">202</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are the most commonly used techniques for the study of phenomena at battery interfaces and interphases. AFM techniques are sensitive to the roughness of the material surface, which may lead to erroneous data due to AFM tip-related artefacts.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0203" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0203_R_d63932372e2852" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 203">203</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In contrast with static force microscopy, AFM imaging studies require careful sample preparation for electrode surfaces with high roughness, as demonstrated by Luchkin et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0198_R_d63932372e2857" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - Sci. Rep.">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and Daboss et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0204_R_d63932372e2862" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - Electrochim. Acta">204</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, non-contact imaging modes for in situ studies also minimize such artefacts<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0205" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0205_R_d63932372e2868" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 205 - MethodsX">205</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Embedding and subsequent cross-sectioning of e.g., composite carbonaceous negative electrode materials via mechanical polishing significantly reduces <i>S</i><sub>z</sub> values (maximum height of a defined area) from several microns to submicron.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0204_R_d63932372e2876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - Electrochim. Acta">204</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This reduction minimizes artifacts and enables the direct observation of SEI formation. Spatially resolved electrochemical measurements obtained via SECM or SECCM, which so far have been done mainly on active particles, e.g., LiMn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0206" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0206_R_d63932372e2886" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 206 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">206</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are less prone to artifacts, particularly in SECM, when microsized electrodes are used, even in constant height<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0207" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0207_R_d63932372e2891" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 207 - Anal. Chem.">207</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or constant distance modes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0208" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0208_R_d63932372e2897" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 208 - Anal. Chem.">208</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>A significant body of literature has been published on interfacial processes at anodes and cathodes of LIBs, including SPM and SEPM studies on interphase formation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0209" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0209_R_d63932372e2904" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 209 - ChemElectroChem">209</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0213" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0213_R_d63932372e2904" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 213 - J. Solid State Electrochem.">213</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SEPM techniques, like SECM and pipette-derived techniques like SECCM, have the advantage that they are noncontact techniques. These techniques are primarily used to study processes at Li-ion batteries,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0214" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0214_R_d63932372e2909" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 214 - Curr. Opin. Electrochem.">214</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0215" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0215_R_d63932372e2909" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 215 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">215</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> including: SEI formation on the negative electrode,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0210" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0210_R_d63932372e2914" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 210 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">210</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0216" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0216_R_d63932372e2914" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 216 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">216</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the influence of applied potential and solvent decomposition on electron transfer processes at the electrode,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0217" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0217_R_d63932372e2920" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 217 - Energy Technol.">217</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and visualization of deintercalation processes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0218" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0218_R_d63932372e2925" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 218 - Nat. Commun.">218</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These techniques are also able to observe dynamic changes in relation to the formation of interphases (e.g., by electrolyte degradation), electrochemical properties of the interface during cycling, fluxes towards electrodes, and the influence of such processes on battery performance. The application of SECM holds promise in addressing scientific challenges at bulk processes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0219" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0219_R_d63932372e2931" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 219 - Anal. Chem.">219</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for example, by relating spatially resolved visualization of the activity of the electrode and interface to bulk properties, and surface processes<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0209" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0209_R_d63932372e2936" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 209 - ChemElectroChem">209</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> at anodes and cathodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0220" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0220_R_d63932372e2941" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 220 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">220</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0221" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0221_R_d63932372e2941" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">221</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>With SECCM local charging/discharging experiments can be performed at single particles in situ without the influence of neighboring particles which is highly interesting for composite electrode materials. Even if expensive ionic liquids and electrolytes or expensive samples are used, only a tiny surface area (e.g., 1 µm<sup>2</sup>) is exposed to the electrolyte thus saving on materials and resources. SPM is nondestructive and all techniques can operate in solution avoiding potentially altering cleaning and drying steps before characterizing the materials. The achieved resolution depends on the used probe and for AFM based techniques lies in the (sub-) nm range, and in the µm range for microelectrodes (e.g., SECM), respectively. Samples need to be flat (<i>S</i><sub>z</sub> &lt; 6 µm) which is hardly ever the case for battery composite materials and needs additional preparation, e.g., by embedding the sample and polishing the surface. Force spectroscopic measurements may provide quantitative nanomechanical information, e.g., Young's modulus of battery components.</p>
            
            <p>The effectiveness of the SEI in blocking electrons and preventing electrolyte decomposition while remaining stable during (de)intercalation, is closely associated with local electron transfer kinetics. SECM has been used to visualize the heterogeneities of the local electrochemical activity on the electrode surface that arise during in situ SEI formation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0209" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0209_R_d63932372e2957" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 209 - ChemElectroChem">209</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0210" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0210_R_d63932372e2957" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 210 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">210</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0216" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0216_R_d63932372e2957" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 216 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">216</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SECM probes employing alternating current (AC) mode can use potentiometric electrodes, which allow for the mapping of ionic fluxes of Li<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup> and determination of the dielectric permittivity and ionic resistivity of the SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0222" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0222_R_d63932372e2966" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Electrochem. Commun.">222</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0223" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0223_R_d63932372e2966" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 223 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">223</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>A challenge, but an important aspect for composite electrodes and heterogeneous samples, is the correlation of electrochemical to morphological and nanomechanical properties, which provides local structure-activity information. Recently, hybrid SPM techniques<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0224" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0224_R_d63932372e2974" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 224 - Annu. Rev. Anal. Chem.">224</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0226" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0226_R_d63932372e2974" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 226 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">226</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> like AFM-SECM<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0227" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0227_R_d63932372e2979" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 227">227</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been used in battery research to get insight into interfacial processes, such as spatially resolved electrochemical information, nanomechanical properties (e.g., adhesion properties, Young's modulus), aging processes, and interphase formation.</p>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">So far, only a limited number of SPM studies have appeared on post-Li battery electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0200" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0200_R_d63932372e2987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 200 - Nano Lett.">200</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0202_R_d63932372e2987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - Nano Lett.">202</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0204_R_d63932372e2987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - Electrochim. Acta">204</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0228_R_d63932372e2987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Electrochem. Sci. Adv.">228</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0232" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0232_R_d63932372e2987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 232 - Energy Storage Mater.">232</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SIBs are considered to be the most promising and technologically most developed next generation battery chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0233" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0233_R_d63932372e2992" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 233 - J. Mater. Chem. A">233</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0234_R_d63932372e2992" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - J. Phys. Energy">234</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, different results have been published in respect to the effect of additives or the used cathode material<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0043_R_d63932372e2997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0071" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0071_R_d63932372e2997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 71 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">71</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0131" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0131_R_d63932372e2997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 131 - ChemElectroChem">131</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0235" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0235_R_d63932372e2997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 235 - Electrochem. Commun.">235</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0236" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0236_R_d63932372e2997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 236 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">236</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and redissolution of SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0237" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0237_R_d63932372e3003" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 237 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">237</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SEPM techniques have been employed to study the SEI formation in embedded cross-sections of negative electrodes, such as highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0198_R_d63932372e3008" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - Sci. Rep.">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> mesocarbon microbeads, graphite, graphene<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0231" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0231_R_d63932372e3014" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - ChemElectroChem">231</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0198_R_d63932372e3019" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - Sci. Rep.">198</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0204_R_d63932372e3019" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - Electrochim. Acta">204</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0017">17</a> shows SECM studies on spray-coated HC composite anodes (Kuranode hard carbon, Kuraray, Japan) for SIBs. The pristine electrode reveals uniform conductivity, which is reflected by the positive feedback response, as evidenced by approach curves recorded at multiple positions using ferrocene (Fc) as redox active species added to solution (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0017">17a</a>). After 40 galvanostatic charge–discharge cycles versus Na<sup>+</sup>/Na (0.1 C, 1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC), the SECM image (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0017">17b</a>) reveals consistent negative feedback across the entire surface, which is corroborated by the approach curves obtained at marked positions. This indicates that a uniform, blocking interphase was formed. The dimensionless heterogeneous substrate kinetics parameter <i>κ</i> can be derived from the current expression displayed in Equation 3, where the current is expressed as a function of RG (ratio between the insulator thickness <i>r</i><sub>glass</sub> and the radius of the microelectrode <i>r</i><sub>T</sub>), <i>L</i> (ratio of distance to <i>r</i><sub>T</sub>) and <i>κ</i>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0238" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0238_R_d63932372e3059" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 238 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">238</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>

               <div class="inline-equation" id="aenm202302830-disp-0004"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE-->
                     <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/1a400973-974e-4864-b340-576005cec66f/aenm202302830-math-0004.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0004" display="block" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0004.png">

                              <msup>
                                 <mi>L</mi>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mn>0.006</mn>

                                 </mrow>

                                 <mrow>

                           </mrow>
                           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">$$\begin{equation}a\ = \ {L}^{0.006{\mathrm{\ RG}} + 0.113}{\kappa }^{ - 0.0236{\mathrm{\ RG}} + 0.91}\end{equation}$$</annotation>

            </div>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0017"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/c5bb1ddf-c9cd-46a8-93cc-72a5663e7b48/aenm202302830-fig-0017-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/c5bb1ddf-c9cd-46a8-93cc-72a5663e7b48/aenm202302830-fig-0017-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/3a449f1b-9f9c-400a-91f3-aff5ddda28d0/aenm202302830-fig-0017-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/c5bb1ddf-c9cd-46a8-93cc-72a5663e7b48/aenm202302830-fig-0017-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 17<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0017&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">SECM feedback images of pristine (a, left) and cycled (b, right) hard carbon composite anodes (40 cycles in 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC). The marked points in the images indicate locations where the approach curves (right) were recorded (black: experimental and red: corresponding theoretical fit). c) SECM feedback images of a multilayer graphene electrode in 0.1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaBF<sub>4</sub> at OCP (left), 1.3 V (middle) and 2.9 V (right) versus ferrocene (Fc/Fc<sup>+</sup>). The scale shows the ratio between the tip current to the current obtained in bulk (<i>I</i><sub>T</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>T, ∞</sub>). Adapted with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0231" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0231_R_d63932372e3207" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - ChemElectroChem">231</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Approach curves were recorded using an ultramicroelectrode (<i>r</i> = 1.5 µm, RG = 40). Positive feedback was obtained for the pristine HC with <i>κ</i> = 1.32 ± 0.18 (<i>n</i> = 8) and negative feedback at cycled HC (40 cycles) with <i>κ</i> = 0.24 ± 0.09 (<i>n</i> = 8), indicating the insulating nature of the formed SEI. The effective heterogeneous substrate kinetics constant <i>κ</i><sub>eff</sub> (<i>κ</i><sub>eff</sub> = <i>κ</i> ⋅ <i>D</i> ⋅ <i>r</i><sup>−1</sup>) was extracted using <i>D</i> = 2.24&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−5</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0239" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0239_R_d63932372e3245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 239 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">239</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and <i>r</i> = 1.5&nbsp;µm. <i>κ</i><sub>eff</sub> decreased from 0.1978 ± 0.0262 cm s<sup>−1</sup> for pristine composite electrode to 0.0360 ± 0.0139 cm s<sup>−1</sup> in the case of the cycled electrode. Zeng et&nbsp;al. conducted a study on the initial formation of the SEI on multilayer graphene electrodes in NaBF<sub>4</sub> in EC:PC, quantifying the passivation and cation uptake using SECM.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0231" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0231_R_d63932372e3263" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - ChemElectroChem">231</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A nonconductive growing interphase was found due to passivation of the electrode (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0017">17c</a>).</p>
            
            <p>As shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0017">17</a>, SEI formation and the ability of the formed SEI, e.g., on HC electrodes, to block electron transfer can be studied via SEPM.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0110">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0110-title">3.8 X-Ray Diffraction (XRD)</h3>
            
            <p>In the context of SIBs XRD (and also neutron diffraction) is predominantly utilized for structural characterization of the hard carbon material, i.e., on the anode side of the cells. Here, XRD allows for determining relevant structural parameters of different carbon materials, for instance to relate the performance in the SIB with specific structural motifs of HC. Note that from a formal point of view it is more appropriate to use the term “Wide-angle X-ray Scattering” compared to “XRD,” as these HC materials feature a marked degree of structural disorder, which results in quite diffuse scattering maxima.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0240" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0240_R_d63932372e3286" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 240 - Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem.">240</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This point is not only a matter of terminology, as the substantial disorder of the graphene stacks pertains to the interpretation of the experimental data (see below). Nevertheless, to avoid confusion, here we continue with “XRD.” Commonly, the average interlayer spacing <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/51a14679-cd4b-4305-8cb8-de46d71897e8/aenm202302830-math-0005.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0005" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0005.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> itself is regarded as the most relevant parameter, which can be extracted from the prominent 002 reflection of HC. Ideally, <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/e67a8bd6-cef0-4cbd-8119-c46ec4e451a7/aenm202302830-math-0006.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0006" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0006.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> can be determined from the position of the 002 reflection <i>2θ</i><sub>002</sub>, applying Bragg's law: <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/7fdaa1c3-4c15-4206-99c6-fee515f19989/aenm202302830-math-0007.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0007" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0007.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> = 2<i>/λ</i> sin (<i>θ</i><sub>002</sub>), with <i>λ</i> being the wavelength used.</p>
            
            <p>For instance, Bommier et&nbsp;al. applied ex situ XRD experiments proving the reversible expansion and contraction of the graphene layers nanosheets of sucrose-derived HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0055_R_d63932372e3335" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - Nano Lett.">55</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As main insight, an intercalation mechanism was identified in the low-potential plateau region.</p>
            
            <p>As important advanced methodology, in situ or operando XRD experiments can be used to peer into the sodium filling mechanism by monitoring fine structural changes in the atomic structure of HC. Again, mainly the parameter <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/99e922ac-bed4-4853-927c-cb2514375a43/aenm202302830-math-0008.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0008" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0008.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> is usually studied, providing insight into the widening/decline of <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/08cf43a6-6262-4531-a21a-b7de98106491/aenm202302830-math-0009.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0009" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0009.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> upon sodiate/desodiation of Na<sup>+</sup> into/out of the interlayer space between the graphene layers. Yet, aside from its position changes in the intensity and width of the 002 reflection can also shed light into the filling mechanism: by such experiments it was recently observed for hard-carbon nanofibers (HCNF) that within the initial sodiation in the slope region, the 002 reflection undergoes narrowing and a decline in intensity, implying that Na<sup>+</sup> ions are inserted between the graphene layers and that NaC<i><sub>x</sub></i> might be formed (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0018">18</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e3376" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Furthermore, treating the HCNF at different temperatures modified <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/acddaf83-3151-4f5e-9c10-abe1fd2cd77b/aenm202302830-math-0010.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0010" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0010.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> which thus allowed for comparison with theoretical predictions for an optimum <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/db82a829-1456-42b5-916d-233b447853c1/aenm202302830-math-0011.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0011" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0011.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> value.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0018"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/407decaf-94ea-4920-aaa6-cb8d24a5bd2d/aenm202302830-fig-0018-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/407decaf-94ea-4920-aaa6-cb8d24a5bd2d/aenm202302830-fig-0018-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/4bdd329a-457c-4d92-9cf5-021614c9fc4b/aenm202302830-fig-0018-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/407decaf-94ea-4920-aaa6-cb8d24a5bd2d/aenm202302830-fig-0018-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 18<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0018&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">In situ characterization of sodium insertion in hard-carbon nano fibers (HCNF<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e3421" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), as a function of carbonization temperature (here 1200 °C–1600 °C). a) In situ Raman spectra and b) in situ XRD patterns of HCNF-1400. c) Schematic illustration for the adsorption/insertion–filling sodium storage mechanism in the HCNFs. d) Schematic illustration for the sodium storage mechanism of HCNF-1200, HCNF-1400, and HCNF-1600, as a function of the interlayer distance. Adapted with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e3426" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>However, as recently pointed out by Chu et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0242" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0242_R_d63932372e3433" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 242 - Adv. Mater.">242</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the characterization of the atomic graphene stack structure of HC should go beyond the average interlayer distance <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/17b1a68c-03ad-46c7-a6f7-487b404d8eaa/aenm202302830-math-0012.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0012" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0012.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> and include further relevant structural parameters such as the graphene layer extension <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> and the stack height <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> (as well as their distribution), and defects in the graphene stacks. The latter comprise point defects within the graphenes themselves and “external” defects at the graphenes’ edge. These parameters can be evaluated from XRD and neutron diffraction data by advanced evaluation methodology, based on two main approaches, namely either fitting the entire XRD curve (i.e. in reciprocal space) by appropriate theoretical functions<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0243" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0243_R_d63932372e3455" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 243 - J. Appl. Crystallogr.">243</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0244" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0244_R_d63932372e3455" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 244 - C">244</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or by calculating the pair-distribution function (PDF).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0055_R_d63932372e3460" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - Nano Lett.">55</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Combining XRD and Raman spectroscopy data suggested that the capacity in the sloping region might not only be related to <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/367f4e72-2ee7-49e6-90b1-b718603e7302/aenm202302830-math-0013.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0013" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0013.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math>, but even dominated by defects in the HC structure.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0055_R_d63932372e3476" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - Nano Lett.">55</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Based on XRD as well as small-angle X-ray scattering, Morikawa et&nbsp;al. found that filling of HC nanopores is a further relevant storage mechanism.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0245" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0245_R_d63932372e3481" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 245 - Adv. Energy Mater.">245</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Among other points, such finding was concluded from the observation that upon deep sodiation in the plateau region the 002 signal does not change, indicating a pore filling mechanism.</p>
            
            <p>The importance of advanced XRD analysis was recently discussed by Glatthaar et&nbsp;al., showing that a precise determination of the average interlayer spacing <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/5d538d2c-14ec-49b7-be2b-2bd04a0969c4/aenm202302830-math-0014.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0014" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0014.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> from the commonly quite broad 002 reflection (or higher order 00<i>l</i> signals) needs a careful consideration of different effects: among others, an asymmetric background (e.g. from the small-angle scattering of nanopores) and the translational disorder in the stacking may affect the position of the maximum of the 002 signal.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0246" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0246_R_d63932372e3502" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 246">246</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It was demonstrated that applying the Bragg equation on the XRD raw data can result in too large <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/0478f407-61a0-4bb8-9687-4b168e970926/aenm202302830-math-0015.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0015" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0015.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> values, especially for HC with pronounced disorder. While the observed discrepancy of up to ca. 0.2 Å for samples treated up to moderate temperatures up to 1300 °C might appear minor, theoretical approaches discuss fine differences <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/c06c4616-1b3b-49cc-a207-4e7e3a39092a/aenm202302830-math-0016.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0016" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0016.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> affecting the energy for sodium insertion and thus changing the storage mechanisms in SIB.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0246" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0246_R_d63932372e3528" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 246">246</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Hence, given the typical range of <span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/d5163638-bd41-4513-a896-5adac32896eb/aenm202302830-math-0017.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:16146832:media:aenm202302830:aenm202302830-math-0017" display="inline" location="graphic/aenm202302830-math-0017.png">
                  <semantics>
                     <msub>
                        <mover accent="true">
                           <mi>a</mi>
                           <mo>¯</mo>
                        </mover>
                        <mn>3</mn>
                     </msub>
                     <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">${\bar{a}}_3$</annotation>
                  </semantics></math> values (ca. 0.34 to 0.4 nm), such potential uncertainty is relevant and requires further detailed state-of-the-art XRD and neutron diffraction analysis.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0120">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0120-title">3.9 Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM)</h3>
            
            <p>Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) has played a crucial role in enhancing our understanding of the influence of structure and defects on the performance of batteries and battery materials and the structural changes involved during charge and discharge cycles. Using STEM, it is possible to track and analyze these changes down to the atomic scale, such as the phase transitions observed at the surface of various oxides<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0247" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0247_R_d63932372e3553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 247 - Nature">247</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0248" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0248_R_d63932372e3553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 248 - Nat. Commun.">248</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or the growth of Na/Li dendrites in solid electrolytes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0249" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0249_R_d63932372e3558" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 249 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">249</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0250" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0250_R_d63932372e3558" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 250 - Nature">250</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Studying these structural transformations can help to elucidate the degradation mechanisms and to shed light on the electrochemical processes in battery materials.</p>
            
            <p>The principle of STEM is similar to SEM, but with the key distinction that the forward scattered or transmitted electrons are used for imaging. This requires higher kinetic energy for the electrons (typically 60–300 keV), resulting in a shorter electron wavelength, smaller interaction volume and thus higher resolution capabilities. Additionally, the specimen under examination must be electron transparent, typically with a thickness below 100&nbsp;nm.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0251" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0251_R_d63932372e3566" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 251">251</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>When the incoming electron wave interacts with the atomic structure, it can either pass through the specimen without interaction or undergo elastic and inelastic scattering. The elastically scattered electrons are classified based on their scattering angle. High-angle scattered electrons (&gt;3°), as a result of the coulomb interaction between the incoming electrons and the atomic nucleus, are incoherent and their intensity is influenced by the atomic number (<i>Z</i>) of the elements present within the specimen. These waves can be detected using an annular-shaped detector with contrast is proportional to <i>Z</i><sup>1.5–2</sup>, forming a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) image.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0252" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0252_R_d63932372e3578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 252">252</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">On the other hand, low-angle scattered electrons (&lt;3°) are mostly coherent and can interfere with each other, producing a diffraction pattern. The electron diffraction pattern is generated based on Bragg's law, which relates the scattering angle to the crystal lattice spacing for constructive interference. As shown in, when scanning a nanometer-sized probe over the specimen, a series of diffraction patterns is generated at each probe position. These diffraction patterns form a 4D (4D-STEM) dataset, with two dimensions corresponding to the spatial axes and two dimensions representing the spatial frequency components of the diffraction pattern. The information that can be acquired through 4D-STEM includes:

               <ul class="rlist hanging">
                  
                  <li><span class="number">1. </span>Crystallographic orientation mapping: The diffraction patterns of the 4D-STEM data set can be analyzed to determine and map the crystallographic orientation distribution in the specimen, providing insights into grain boundaries, phases present and texture variations<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0253" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0253_R_d63932372e3590" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 253 - Microsc. Microanal.">253</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as well as mapping the lithiation state if it is associated with sufficient crystallographic change.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0254" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0254_R_d63932372e3595" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 254 - Ultramicroscopy">254</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></li>
                  
                  <li><span class="number">2. </span>Strain and deformation mapping: The analysis of the diffraction patterns in 4D-STEM allows for the characterization of strain and deformation fields within the sample. By comparing the diffraction patterns with a reference pattern, changes in lattice spacing and crystal distortions can be quantified, providing insights into the mechanical properties and stress distribution of the material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0250" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0250_R_d63932372e3603" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 250 - Nature">250</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></li>
                  
                  <li><span class="number">3. </span>Charge distribution analysis: By utilizing differential phase contrast (DPC) techniques in conjunction with 4D-STEM, information about the charge distribution and charge field can be extracted. In 4D-STEM DPC, the deflection of the central diffraction disc is measured. This deflection is caused by the interaction of the primary electron beam with the electric field within the specimen. By analyzing the extent and direction of the deflection, it is in principle possible to gain insights into the electric field and charge density of the material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0255" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0255_R_d63932372e3611" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 255 - Nat. Commun.">255</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></li>
               </ul>
            </div>
            
            <p>By combining 4D-STEM with DPC and other spectroscopic techniques, such as electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) and EDS it becomes possible to obtain compositional information and insights into the electronic structure, including bond type, oxidation state, and bandgap alongside the crystal orientation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0256" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0256_R_d63932372e3619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 256 - Appl. Phys. Lett.">256</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0257" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0257_R_d63932372e3619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 257 - Nano Lett.">257</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Recently, Hughes et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0258" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0258_R_d63932372e3626" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 258 - Microsc. Microanal.">258</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> employed 4D-STEM and EELS to investigate the strain and chemical evolution at the solid electrolyte-electrode interface. This study focuses on understanding the structural changes and chemical composition variations occurring at the interface during battery cycling. This combination provides a comprehensive understanding of the SEI and its impact on battery performance. The reliable preparation of STEM samples is crucial for meaningful investigations, especially when dealing with materials sensitive to electron beam irradiation. The most commonly used method for targeted preparation is focused ion beam (FIB), but the structural modifications caused by FIB are not well understood for various materials. Ziming et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0259" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0259_R_d63932372e3631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 259 - Advanced Energy Materials. Portico">259</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the impact of both the electron and Ga<sup>+</sup> ion beam on insulating solid-state electrolytes, including lithium phosphorus oxynitride, Na-β″-alumina solid electrolyte (BASE), and Na<sub>3.4</sub>Si<sub>2.4</sub>Zr<sub>2</sub>P<sub>0.6</sub>O<sub>12</sub> (NaSICON). The researchers observed significant growth of lithium/sodium whiskers induced by both beams, even at low doses, resulting in a notable change in the chemical composition. This whisker growth is likely due to surface charging, which can be mitigated by coating the sample with a layer of gold or preparing it under cryogenic conditions (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0019">19</a>).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0019"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/877dd6c3-0d57-455c-89e2-68dba3496bd0/aenm202302830-fig-0019-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/877dd6c3-0d57-455c-89e2-68dba3496bd0/aenm202302830-fig-0019-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/23c33ff0-5009-4761-9ac2-c1aa57d17118/aenm202302830-fig-0019-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/877dd6c3-0d57-455c-89e2-68dba3496bd0/aenm202302830-fig-0019-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 19<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0019&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">4D-STEM on a Na-β″-alumina solid electrolyte: a) Principle of 4D-STEM, b) array of diffraction patterns and c) inverse pole figure highlighting the crystal orientation distribution map.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>STEM and 4D-STEM can be employed in situ to investigate Na-ion transport in a solid electrolyte to understand the role of the microstructure on sodium diffusion and dendrite formation. <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0020">20</a> demonstrates the utilization of STEM imaging along with 4D-STEM orientation mapping for visualizing the microstructure of a Na-β″-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> electrolyte and the distribution of Na<sup>+</sup> during biasing. After the 1st cycle, Na<sup>+</sup> diffused to the Au/electrode interface as well as along the grain boundary. This has been verified by STEM-EDS. Furthermore, the results reveal that the Na-ion transport to the Na-β″-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/Au electrode interface depends strongly on the local crystal orientation and sodium dendrite formation occurs at specific grain boundaries (indicated by green arrows).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0259" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0259_R_d63932372e3695" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 259 - Advanced Energy Materials. Portico">259</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0020"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/762b5ee4-044e-4d41-9eff-7f5ff1eac2e2/aenm202302830-fig-0020-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/762b5ee4-044e-4d41-9eff-7f5ff1eac2e2/aenm202302830-fig-0020-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/e5d8ae9e-ead9-4e03-98ff-5668673f71e6/aenm202302830-fig-0020-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/762b5ee4-044e-4d41-9eff-7f5ff1eac2e2/aenm202302830-fig-0020-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 20<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0020&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Formation of Na-filament along the grain boundary: a) 4D-STEM orientation map highlighting the nanocrystalline nature of the Na-β″-alumina. b) HAADF-STEM image of the region marked by the red dashed rectangle in a) and c) is the corresponding Na elemental map showing no enrichment of Na at the interfaces or grain boundaries (marks as white line in b). d) HAADF-STEM image after the first cycling shows the appearance of brighter contrast along the grain boundary. The corresponding STEM-EDS map in <b>e)</b> shows a clear enrichment of Na at the GB.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Here, 4D-STEM is providing the crystallographic orientation information of the grains and thus characterizes the grain boundaries. This information helps to optimize the microstructure to enhance sodium-ion mobility and reduce dendrite formation.</p>
            
            <p>In the literature there are currently only limited publications with TEM dedicated to a detailed structural characterization of HC electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0229" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0229_R_d63932372e3726" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 229 - J. Chem. Phys.">229</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The disordered structure with (sub)nanoscale pores renders classical (S)TEM characterization techniques difficult. However, some recent advanced techniques such as STEM-PDF<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0260" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0260_R_d63932372e3731" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 260 - Microscopy">260</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or high-resolution STEM-EELS<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0261" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0261_R_d63932372e3736" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 261 - Ultramicroscopy">261</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> might provide new insights into the structural changes to elucidate structural changes during electrochemical processes in SIBs.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0130">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0130-title">3.10 Electrochemical Single Electrode Microcalorimetry</h3>
            
            <p>Electrochemical methods like cyclic voltammetry or electrochemical impedance spectroscopy are based on the measurement of the electrode potential as a function of current or charge. From a thermodynamic point of view, since the (equilibrium) cell voltage is related to the free enthalpy of the cell reaction, Δ<sub><i>R</i></sub><i>G</i>, the measurement of the potential corresponds to the determination of Δ<sub><i>R</i></sub><i>G</i>, as a function of the current or charge, including some deterioration by overpotential. However, there are other thermodynamic quantities of similar significance that are worth considering. Here, we will discuss the measurement of the heat, which is evolved at a single electrode, that is, e.g., in one half-cell of a battery system, as a function of current or potential and time.
