In general, the heat <i>q</i> evolved upon an electrode reaction can be separated<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3761" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0264" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0264_R_d63932372e3761" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 264 - Curr. Opin. Electrochem.">264</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> into two parts, <i>q</i> = <i>q</i><sub>rev</sub> + <i>q</i><sub>irrev</sub>. The reversibly exchanged heat, <i>q</i><sub>rev</sub>, changes its sign upon reversal of the current flow. It corresponds to the heat, which is evolved or absorbed during an infinitely slow process at the electrode–electrolyte junction close to thermodynamic equilibrium. It is also called Peltier heat. In real electrochemical systems, the reactions proceed within finite time, driven by overpotential, which will lead to the production of additional, irreversible heat, <i>q</i><sub>irrev</sub>, due to deviation from thermodynamic equilibrium. The reversibly exchanged (Peltier) heat at a single electrode is directly related to the entropy change of the electrochemical reaction, Δ<i><sub>R</sub>S</i>. However, since ions and electrons are transported across the border of the half-cell during the reaction, their heat of transport<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3786" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> has to be considered, which leads to a “correction” of the usual formula for the reaction entropy by the entropy of transfer, Δ<i><sub>T</sub>S</i>. The reaction entropy is then given by: Δ<i><sub>R</sub>S</i> = <i>q</i><sub>rev</sub>/<i>T</i> + Δ<i><sub>T</sub>S</i>, where <i>T</i> is the temperature of the isothermal system.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3812" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0264" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0264_R_d63932372e3812" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 264 - Curr. Opin. Electrochem.">264</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In aqueous systems Δ<sub><i>T</i></sub><i>S</i> can often be explicitly calculated from literature values of the heat of transport. For nonaqueous systems the transport “correction” might be more difficult to determine, however, approximations exist.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3821" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, in many systems Δ<i><sub>T</sub>S</i> is small compared to the reaction entropy of the electrochemical electrode reaction.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3831" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0263" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0263_R_d63932372e3831" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 263 - J. Electroanal. Chem. Interfacial Electrochem.">263</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Most methods for the measurement of heat evolution or absorption at a single electrode rely on the measurement of temperature changes either of the electrode itself or the complete half-cell upon the electrochemical reaction. Traditional approaches are summarized, e.g., in references.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0262_R_d63932372e3838" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262">262</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0263" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0263_R_d63932372e3838" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 263 - J. Electroanal. Chem. Interfacial Electrochem.">263</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0265" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0265_R_d63932372e3838" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 265 - Inorg. Chim. Acta">265</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> For an experimental setup reaching sub-monolayer sensitivity see, e.g., <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0021">21</a> and ref. [<span><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0266" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0266_R_d63932372e3847" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 266 - Rev. Sci. Instrum.">266</a></span>].</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0021"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/f2868c74-d622-4376-ba55-c84d97fba349/aenm202302830-fig-0021-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/f2868c74-d622-4376-ba55-c84d97fba349/aenm202302830-fig-0021-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/fbb2017f-8914-42b3-96e7-0cf64747d9ea/aenm202302830-fig-0021-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/f2868c74-d622-4376-ba55-c84d97fba349/aenm202302830-fig-0021-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 21<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0021&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Sketch of a microcalorimeter for which a detailed version can be found in ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0266" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0266_R_d63932372e3870" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 266 - Rev. Sci. Instrum.">266</a></span>] The temperature of a thin working electrode (1) is measured at its backside by a thin pyroelectric sensor (2). On top of the working electrode the electrochemical cell (3) with counter and reference electrodes (4, 5) is mounted.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>An early application of single electrode microcalorimetry for the measurement of Peltier heats in battery systems dealt with zinc and bromine electrodes in zinc–bromine and zinc–air batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0267" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0267_R_d63932372e3877" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 267 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">267</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Rather large conversions of up to 1 C were necessary, due to a relatively bulky electrode-thermistor setup.Recently, single electrode microcalorimetry was demonstrated for Li and Na bulk deposition in order to determine the reaction entropy in carbonate and diglyme based electrolytes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0268" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0268_R_d63932372e3882" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 268 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">268</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0269_R_d63932372e3882" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">269</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In both cases, conversions below a few percent of a metal monolayer were employed. It should be noted that calorimetry is also effective at studying these properties in full cells, where the complete cell is immersed in the calorimeter. Using this method, e.g., Dahn et&nbsp;al. studied the reaction entropy of Li intercalation into Li<i><sub>x</sub></i>Mo<sub>6</sub>Se<sub>8</sub> versus a Li electrode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0270" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0270_R_d63932372e3895" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 270 - Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.">270</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> For more recent applications see, e.g., ref. [<span><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0271" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0271_R_d63932372e3899" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 271 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">271</a></span>]. In addition, the Peltier heat and reaction entropy of single electrodes is also attainable using thermocells, cells where the electrodes are kept at different temperatures (see, e.g., refs. [<span><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0272" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0272_R_d63932372e3902" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 272 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">272</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0273" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0273_R_d63932372e3902" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 273 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">273</a></span>] and references therein). Another popular approach for the study of the reaction entropy of battery systems, known as entropy profiling, involves measuring the temperature coefficient of the equilibrium cell potential.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0274_R_d63932372e3907" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - Phys. Rev. B">274</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0276" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0276_R_d63932372e3907" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 276 - ChemPhysChem">276</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>An example of single-electrode microcalorimetry is shown in <b>Figure</b>&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0022">22</a>, which displays current, potential, electrode temperature and heat transients for Na deposition (left) and Na dissolution (right) on a thick Na film in 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaClO<sub>4</sub>/PC by 10 ms long current pulses with amplitudes of −0.3 and +0.3 mA, respectively (see first row of Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0022">22</a>). The potential (second row) essentially follows the current pulses, indicating negligible mass transport limitations. For Na deposition (left) the electrode temperature decreased linearly during the current pulse, signaling cooling of the electrode with a constant heat flux. After the pulse, the temperature relaxed towards the original temperature by thermal equilibration with the environment. The bottom row gives the total heat, which was determined from the temperature transients, and which was liberated or absorbed up to time <i>t</i> by the electrochemical reactions. Upon reversal of the current pulse polarity (right panel) all transients are almost quantitatively reversed, signaling the high reversibility of the Na deposition reaction under the studied reaction conditions. For further details and a discussion of the implications of the reaction entropy obtained from these measurements see ref. [<span><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0269_R_d63932372e3928" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">269</a></span>]. The time dependence of the total exchanged heat can also be obtained with single electrode microcalorimetry. This provides insights into the transport mechanisms of Na<sup>+</sup> into and through the SEI.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0277" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0277_R_d63932372e3934" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 277 - Angewandte Chemie International Edition. Portico">277</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Microcalorimetric measurements can also be conducted with HC electrodes, as long as they are thin enough to ensure fast heat transfer to the pyroelectric sensor.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0133" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0133_R_d63932372e3940" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 133 - Batteries Supercaps">133</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0022"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9d9433ba-4dec-4286-a041-98be06613536/aenm202302830-fig-0022-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9d9433ba-4dec-4286-a041-98be06613536/aenm202302830-fig-0022-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/dc380602-0f28-4d90-a83b-6ea564fdb1e6/aenm202302830-fig-0022-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9d9433ba-4dec-4286-a041-98be06613536/aenm202302830-fig-0022-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 22<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0022&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Current, potential, temperature and heat transients for Na deposition and dissolution by 10 ms long current pulses of −0.3 mA and +0.3 mA in 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaClO<sub>4</sub>/propylene carbonate. Upon reversal of the polarity of the current, that is, the direction of the electrochemical reaction, all transients change their signs.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
         </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0140">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0140-title">3.11 Solid-State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (ssNMR)</h3>
            
            <p>Solid-state NMR is a versatile analytical method playing a crucial role in investigation of lithium- and sodium-ion battery<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0278" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0278_R_d63932372e3978" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - Chem. Mater.">278</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0279" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0279_R_d63932372e3978" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 279 - Adv. Mater.">279</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> materials and systems, such as carbon,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0280" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0280_R_d63932372e3983" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 280 - Chem. Rec.">280</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<i><sub>x</sub></i>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0281" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0281_R_d63932372e3996" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 281 - ACS Nano">281</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Sb,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0282" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0282_R_d63932372e4001" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 282 - Trans. Tianjin Univ.">282</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> SiCN,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0283" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0283_R_d63932372e4007" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 283 - Batteries Supercaps">283</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Sn,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0284_R_d63932372e4012" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0285" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0285_R_d63932372e4026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Nanoscale">285</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>2±</sub><i><sub>x</sub></i>V<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>13</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0286" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0286_R_d63932372e4042" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 286 - J. Mater. Chem. A">286</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>F,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0287" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0287_R_d63932372e4058" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 287 - Chem. Mater.">287</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>3</sub>PS<sub>4</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0288" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0288_R_d63932372e4068" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 288 - J. Mater. Chem. A">288</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>2+2</sub><i><sub>x</sub></i>Fe<sub>2−</sub><i><sub>x</sub></i>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0289" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0289_R_d63932372e4086" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 289 - Chem. Mater.">289</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)/C,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0290" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0290_R_d63932372e4105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 290 - J. Power Sources">290</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na<sub>2</sub>FePO<sub>4</sub>F,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0291" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0291_R_d63932372e4114" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 291 - Angew. Chem.">291</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> PBA,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0292_R_d63932372e4120" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - Adv. Energy Mater.">292</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0293_R_d63932372e4120" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Mol. Cryst. Liq. Cryst.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and NASICON.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0294" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0294_R_d63932372e4125" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 294 - eScience">294</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">The natural availability of a variety of atomic sensors across the periodic table, like nuclear spins as <sup>1</sup>H, <sup>2</sup>D, <sup>6,7</sup>Li, <sup>11</sup>B, <sup>13</sup>C, <sup>14,15</sup>N, <sup>19</sup>F, <sup>23</sup>Na, <sup>25</sup>Mg, <sup>27</sup>Al, <sup>29</sup>Si, <sup>31</sup>P, <sup>33</sup>S, <sup>35</sup>Cl, <sup>39</sup>K, <sup>51</sup>V, <sup>119</sup>Sn, etc., are of considerable value probing local structure, mobility, formation, transfer, reaction, and degradation mechanisms. It's wealth of information relies on nuclear spin interactions of atomic level perturbations in the energetic order of 10<sup>−7</sup>–10<sup>−15</sup> eV. Aside from the basic Zeeman contribution due to the applied external magnetic field, a couple of nuclear spin interactions are naturally present:

               <ul class="rlist hanging">
                  
                  <li><span class="number">a) </span>Shift contributions (chemical shift: CS, Fermi contact shift: FCS, Pseudo contact shift: PCS, Knight shift: KS, magnetic susceptibility shift: MSS and induced current shift: ICS)</li>
                  
                  <li><span class="number">b) </span>Nuclear spin couplings (direct nuclear spin coupling: DNC, indirect nuclear spin coupling: INC)</li>
                  
                  <li><span class="number">c) </span>Direct nuclear spin to unpaired electron spin distribution couplings (DNEC)</li>
                  
                  <li><span class="number">d) </span>Quadrupolar interaction (QI).see <b>Table</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202302830-tbl-0001">1</a>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0278" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0278_R_d63932372e4195" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - Chem. Mater.">278</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></li>
                  </ul>
            </div>
            
            <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202302830-tbl-0001">
               
               
               
               
               <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  1.
                    </span>NMR interaction types, their short description/origin and information content obtained from related spectral features (*MAS:<sup>[</sup><span class="section-footNote"><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0295" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0295_R_d63932372e4212" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - J. Magn. Reson.">295</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0296" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0296_R_d63932372e4212" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - Chem. Rev.">296</a></sup></span></span><sup>]</sup> magic angle spinning to average out anisotropic interactions and **MW: microwave irradiation to decouple the electron spins from the nuclear spin,<sup>[</sup><span class="section-footNote"><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0297" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0297_R_d63932372e4217" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">297</a></sup></span></span><sup>]</sup> both methods are useful for spectral resolution enhancement)</header>
               
               
               
               <div class="article-table-content-wrapper" tabindex="0">
                  <table class="table article-section__table">
                     
                     
                     
                     
                     
                     <thead>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <th colspan="2" class="bottom-bordered-cell right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Type</th>
                           
                           <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Description</th>
                           
                           <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Information content</th>
                           </tr>
                        </thead>
                     
                     <tbody>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td rowspan="6" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Shifts</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">CS</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">(De)shielding of the external magnetic field due to local valence electrons and through space effects</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Site specific differentiation of <sup>1</sup>H, <sup>6,7</sup>Li, <sup>11</sup>B, <sup>13</sup>C, <sup>19</sup>F, <sup>23</sup>Na, <sup>27</sup>Al, <sup>31</sup>P, <sup>29</sup>Si, etc. species associated to the electrolyte, graphene-like sheets, SEI and CEI formation with related decompositions (NaF, NaCl, NaOH, NaO<i><sub>x</sub></i>, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>PO<i><sub>y</sub></i>, etc.)</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">FC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Field shift due to the acting isotropic part of unpaired electrons</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Isotropic influence of radicals (within carbon, electrolyte, binder, etc.) and paramagnetic species (impurities, hetero-atoms and/or additives) depends on spin density, proximity, and temperature</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">PCS</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Field shift due to the anisotropic part of unpaired electrons</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Anisotropic influence of radicals and paramagnetic species, see row above</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">KS</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Shift effect of the unpaired conduction band electrons</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Metallic species to be identified (macroscopic metal contributions are mostly silent due to the Faraday effect and induced currents but may introduce magnetic susceptibility effects onto nearby material distributions)</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">MSS</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Overall magnetic susceptibility effect</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Nearby and surrounding second order (nano- to microscale) material formations: graphene-like sheet, pore, binder, electrolyte, additive distributions, and densities</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">ICS</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Field shifts due to induced currents</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">During spinning (MAS*) of locally conductive materials within a magnetic field, local currents can be induced which produce&nbsp; an opposite field (shift dependence on the spinning speed)</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td rowspan="2" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Nucl. Dipole Couplings</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">DNC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Direct homonuclear and heteronuclear spin interaction (through space)</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Proximity and distance information, distance encoding ≈1/<i>r</i><sup>3</sup></td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">INC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Indirect homonuclear and heteronuclear spin interaction (through bonds)</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">If spectroscopically resolvable it provides information about bond structures, hybridizations, coordination, and bond-order (e.g., coupling via 3, 4 or 5 bonds), e.g., electrolyte and (de)compositions</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td colspan="2" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Quadrupole interactions (QI)</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Quadrupolar moments (<i>Q</i><sub>m</sub>) interact with the surrounding electric field gradient (EFG) of the local electron distribution</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">For nuclei with suitable large <i>Q<sub>m</sub></i> (<sup>2</sup>D, <sup>6,7</sup>Li <sup>11</sup>B, <sup>14</sup>N, <sup>17</sup>O, <sup>23</sup>Na, <sup>25</sup>Mg, <sup>27</sup>Al, <sup>33</sup>S, <sup>35</sup>Cl, <sup>39</sup>K, <sup>43</sup>Ca, <sup>51</sup>V, etc.) information about coordination, crystal order and mobility can be obtained but may often lead to broad spectral features, i.e., advanced experimental techniques are needed (MQ-NMR and ultra-fast NMR).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0300" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0300_R_d63932372e4437" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 300 - Annu. Rev. Mater. Res.">300</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td colspan="2" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">DNEC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Direct nuclear to electron spin coupling through space</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">An average electron spin distribution due to radicals or transition metals will considerably broaden NMR spectral features requesting decoupling efforts (ultra-fast MAS or MW** irradiation).</td>
                           </tr>
                        </tbody>
                     </table>
               </div>
               
               
               <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
            </div>
            
            <p>Due to these internal interactions, for <sup>6,7</sup>Li- and <sup>23</sup>Na-NMR, the different components of an electrochemical cell (anode, cathode, electrolyte, binders, additives) span a large shift range from +1500 to −50 ppm, see <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0023">23</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0023"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/29cc3655-d955-44f3-9ffa-1ab2f968f8fb/aenm202302830-fig-0023-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/29cc3655-d955-44f3-9ffa-1ab2f968f8fb/aenm202302830-fig-0023-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/15403be7-a3e1-4455-a879-ebcb7484a3dc/aenm202302830-fig-0023-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/29cc3655-d955-44f3-9ffa-1ab2f968f8fb/aenm202302830-fig-0023-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 23<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0023&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematics of current scope of the advancing ssNMR with its applications in battery characterization. Static-, MAS NMR and imaging has been used for ex situ, in situ, and operando methodologies to gain information about sites, dynamics and morphology. Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0316" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0316_R_d63932372e4491" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 316 - J. Mater. Chem. A">316</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2020, Royal Society of Chemistry; Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0302" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0302_R_d63932372e4496" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 302 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">302</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society; Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0317" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0317_R_d63932372e4501" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 317 - Nat. Commun.">317</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2017, Springer; Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0318" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0318_R_d63932372e4507" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 318 - J. Phys. Chem. Lett.">318</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2018, ACS Publications; Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0319" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0319_R_d63932372e4512" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 319 - ChemPhysChem">319</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2012, Wiley-VCH27; Reproduced with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0278" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0278_R_d63932372e4518" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - Chem. Mater.">278</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2017, ACS Publications.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>As sketched in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0022">23</a>, solid-state NMR methods can be classified into two branches: static and MAS methodologies applied to ex situ, in situ and operando setups to investigate sites/species, dynamics, transport paths/rates and spatial resolved properties (MRI).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0298" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0298_R_d63932372e4529" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - Nat. Commun.">298</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0299" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0299_R_d63932372e4529" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - Mater. Today">299</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">However, several limitations have to be considered:

               <ul class="unordered-list">
                  
                  <li>NMR distinguishability is based on magnetically non-identical sites</li>
                  
                  <li>Nuclear spins become silent in the proximity of unpaired electron spins (e.g., Fe, Mn, Ni, Co, etc.)</li>
                  
                  <li>Some nuclear sensors provide a reduced sensitivity due to their low abundance, low gamma and large quadrupolar coupling (e.g., <sup>17</sup>O, <sup>25</sup>Mg, <sup>33</sup>S and <sup>35</sup>Cl).</li>
                  </ul>
            </div>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">Major advantages of ssNMR are:

               <ul class="unordered-list">
                  
                  <li>Applicable to different phases (liquid, gel, crystal, amorphous and metallic)</li>
                  
                  <li>Availability of a variety of nuclear sensors</li>
                  
                  <li>Sensitivity to couple of nuclear interactions’ variations due to structural and morphological influences (bonds, coordination, grain boundaries, geometry frustrations, core/shell, surfaces, phases, mobilities, etc.)</li>
                  
                  <li>Probe for paramagnetic influences (shifts, line-broadening, and relaxation behavior).</li>
                  </ul>
            </div>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element"><sup>23</sup>Na ssNMR has been applied to identify different Na-species like:

               <ul class="unordered-list">
                  
                  <li>Solvated ions (electrolyte, e.g., NaClO<sub>4</sub> or NaPF<sub>6</sub>),</li>
                  
                  <li>Adsorbed at defects, surfaces, and edges,</li>
                  
                  <li>SEI formation, originating from degenerated electrolyte (Na<sub>2</sub>O, NaOH, NaCl, NaF, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>P<i><sub>y</sub></i> and Na<i><sub>x</sub></i>PO<i><sub>y</sub></i>);<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0278" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0278_R_d63932372e4602" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - Chem. Mater.">278</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></li>
                  
                  <li>Intercalated between sheets,</li>
                  
                  <li>Metallic fillings in pores</li>
                  </ul>
            </div>
            
            <p>Two of the biggest challenges for HC in SIBs<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0234_R_d63932372e4614" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - J. Phys. Energy">234</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0279" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0279_R_d63932372e4614" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 279 - Adv. Mater.">279</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0301_R_d63932372e4614" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - Carbon">301</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are 1) storage capacity and 2) uncontrolled SEI degradation. Both can be monitored by ssNMR. Improved insight, especially improved spectral site-specific identification with structural localization, is expected to be gained by applying improved multinuclear and multidimensional experiments, ultrafast MAS<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0295" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0295_R_d63932372e4619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - J. Magn. Reson.">295</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0296" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0296_R_d63932372e4619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - Chem. Rev.">296</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>, and in situ MAS NMR<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0303" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0303_R_d63932372e4624" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 303 - J. Magn. Reson.">303</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0304" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0304_R_d63932372e4624" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304">304</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>. For accessing less-sensitive nuclei, a polarization enhancement (DNP) could be applied.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0305" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0305_R_d63932372e4630" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - Isr. J. Chem.">305</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0306" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0306_R_d63932372e4630" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Chem. Rev.">306</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>NMR analytical investigations of LIBs and SIBs mostly follow similar methodologies. However, for the observation of the charge transfer nuclei (<sup>6</sup>Li,&nbsp;<sup>7</sup>Li and&nbsp;<sup>23</sup>Na) exist differences, more between the rarely measured&nbsp;<sup>6</sup>Li versus&nbsp;<sup>7</sup>Li/<sup>23</sup>Na than the most common&nbsp;<sup>7</sup>Li vs.&nbsp;<sup>23</sup>Na, e.g. spin (1, 3/2, 3/2), natural abundance (7.59, 92.41, 100%), chemical shift range (28, 28, 72 ppm—electron density at sodium is larger than lithium most relevant for discriminating diamagnetic contributions), Larmor frequency (14.7, 38.9, 26.4% in respect to 1H), quadrupolar moment (-0.08, -4.01, 10.4 fm<sup>2</sup>) and receptivity (0.001, 0.271, 0.093 in respect to 1H).</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0150">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202302830-sec-0150-title">3.12 Computational Modeling</h3>
            
            <p>In this section, we will briefly discuss several computational analysis methods ranging from atom-scale to cell-scale simulations. Each of these modeling methods has a long history of usage in the study of different battery systems.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0307" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0307_R_d63932372e4666" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307">307</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The majority of these studies have been focused on Li-ion based chemistries. However, there is a growing interest in Na-ion chemistries, and many of the methodologies used in prior Li-ion anode interface studies can be applied to Na-ion systems, too.</p>
            
            <p>Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are the finest-grained method that we will discuss here, they are hallmarked by explicitly accounting for electrons in the form of density fields.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0308" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0308_R_d63932372e4674" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Ann. Phys.">308</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0310" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0310_R_d63932372e4674" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 310 - Mol. Phys.">310</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These calculations can be used to study atom-scale properties such as molecular and surface geometries, reaction energies and barriers, and solvation structures. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) is essentially an extension of DFT onto time-dependent systems.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0311" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0311_R_d63932372e4679" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 311 - Phys. Rev. B">311</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0312" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0312_R_d63932372e4679" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 312">312</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> AIMD allows for the examination of dynamical behavior, such as ion transport and intercalation, solvation behavior, surface evolution, and reactivity. These are known as “first principles” methods, which means they do not need parametrization from experiments or other computational methods. They are highly computationally expensive and are limited to simulating systems on the order of hundreds of atoms at picosecond timescales.</p>
            
            <p>Several recent studies have employed DFT calculations to examine the stability of various electrolytes in Na-ion systems.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0313" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0313_R_d63932372e4687" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 313 - ChemSusChem">313</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0314" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0314_R_d63932372e4687" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 314 - Chem. Mater.">314</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These studies were able to establish reduction mechanisms and energy barriers of common carbonate electrolytes. They established that out of EC/PC/VC, VC is the most likely species to undergo 1-electron reduction to form organic SEI components, and EC is the most likely species to undergo 2-electron reduction to form carbonate SEI components. EC was shown to have the highest reduction potential and lowest reaction barrier, which indicates that EC ring opening is the primary mechanism of SEI growth. VC and FEC were studied as additives for these systems, and were both observed to preferentially react instead of EC. They also raised the reaction barrier of neighboring EC, leading to reduced reactivity and different decomposition pathways.</p>
            
            <p>AIMD calculations have been used in conjunction with experiments to study the effectiveness of Li-pretreated&nbsp;HC electrodes and develop a more detailed understanding of SEI formation in SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0315" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0315_R_d63932372e4695" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - Adv. Energy Mater.">315</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Systems with ether-based electrolytes exhibited better stability than those with carbonate electrolytes during experimental charge cycling, but the mechanism behind this stability was unclear. AIMD calculations revealed that tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME)/Na<sup>+</sup> complexes expand the edges of HC layers, but do not insert between them. They also revealed that TEGDME will readily adsorb onto the HC surface, and that these adsorbed species are able to resist reduction compared to nonadsorbed species (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0024">24a</a>). These findings indicate that the improved cyclability is likely due to the lower reactivity and increased SEI stability of TEGDME compared to carbonates.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0024"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/101741ff-283e-4845-b37d-d097a9d8f326/aenm202302830-fig-0024-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/101741ff-283e-4845-b37d-d097a9d8f326/aenm202302830-fig-0024-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/81a17e7e-92a1-4bc0-beae-1b1afaa2e512/aenm202302830-fig-0024-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/101741ff-283e-4845-b37d-d097a9d8f326/aenm202302830-fig-0024-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 24<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0024&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Snapshot of AIMD simulation of TEGDME at sodiated hard carbon after 45 ps. Reprinted with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0315" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0315_R_d63932372e4729" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - Adv. Energy Mater.">315</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2022, Wiley The black circle indicates where TEGDME has caused expansion of the HC edge layers b) MD-predicted model of HC structure. Reprinted with permission.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0056" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0056_R_d63932372e4734" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 56 - Adv. Energy Mater.">56</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2018, Wiley.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Classical molecular dynamics (MD) calculations consist of atoms and/or molecules with spring-link bonds, where the interactions between species are represented with parametrized force fields, rather than through explicit electronic contributions.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0320" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0320_R_d63932372e4741" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 320 - J. Chem. Phys.">320</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0322" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0322_R_d63932372e4741" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 322">322</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This leads to a substantial reduction in computational cost, which allows for the simulation of tens of thousands of atoms at nanosecond timescales. The larger scale enables the study of thermodynamic properties, diffusion rates, and nanometer-scale changes in surface morphology and electrolyte structure.</p>
            
            <p>Experiments revealed that doping HC with nitrogen (N-HC) in SIBs leads to <i>a</i> ≈39% increase in capacity and improved cycling stability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0323" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0323_R_d63932372e4751" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 323 - Electrochim. Acta">323</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A combination of MD and DFT calculations were employed in order to understand the reason behind this promising behavior. MD calculations were performed to generate example HC geometries, which were then used as inputs for DFT calculations. DFT was then used to study the properties of N-HC and HC during sodiation. It was determined that N-HC underwent significantly less volume expansion than HC (7.9% vs 21.7%). This indicates that nitrogen doping reduces the internal stress in HC during sodiation and is responsible for the increased capacity and stability.</p>
            
            <p>Recent work has combined experimental methods with MD and reverse Monte Carlo calculations in order to develop a better understanding of the binding and storage mechanisms of Na<sup>+</sup> in HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0056" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0056_R_d63932372e4761" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 56 - Adv. Energy Mater.">56</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>XRD and neutron diffraction are the most important methods to determine the interlayer spacing, the relevance of which in sodiation can also be modeled theoretical calculation. DFT calculations can be used to determine the energy cost of Na<sup>+</sup> insertion into the interlayer space, as a function of the value of the interlayer spacing.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e4770" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Such calculations reveal that above an interlayer spacing of 0.37 nm the energetic cost for Na<sup>+</sup> insertion declines drastically, which seems to be in line with XRD analysis.</p>
            
            <p>X-Ray diffraction (XRD), neutron scattering, and pair distribution function analysis were used to study a specific HC sample. MD was then used to mimic the sintering process of HC fabrication on many different initial carbon structures, until a structure with similar density and pair distribution to experimental values was created (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0024">24b</a>). A reverse Monte Carlo algorithm was then used to modify the MD output in order to further improve the fit to experimental data. The resulting geometry was then analyzed in order to identify and quantify the presence of different HC structural features.</p>
            
            <p>More advanced DFT approaches simulate gradually ordered graphene stack structures by machine-learning, simulating temperature annealing including defect sites, and thus generate structures which can potentially be compared with experimental XRD and small-angle X-ray or neutron scattering data in regard to the distribution of metal atoms.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0324" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0324_R_d63932372e4787" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 324 - J. Mater. Chem. A">324</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Additional simulations of Na<sup>+</sup> inserted into the final HC structure were performed in order to identify and quantify binding sites. These binding sites were then paired with energies from previous DFT calculations<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0325" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0325_R_d63932372e4796" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 325 - Chem. Mater.">325</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to correlate them to the experimental charge/discharge voltage profiles. This allowed for the association of specific structural features to the sloping regions of the curve. This work also established a model to characterize HC from different sources.</p>
            
            <p>Kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) models are versatile and can be applied to a wide range of size- and timescales, depending on the properties of the system being simulated. They are often used to study atomistic behavior, where atoms and molecular beads are represented on a lattice. A set of relevant events, such as chemical reactions, and their corresponding rates must be provided as inputs for the system. The kMC model works by sequentially selecting these events based on likelihood and random number generation, and then applying to the system.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0326" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0326_R_d63932372e4804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 326 - Front. Chem.">326</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0327" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0327_R_d63932372e4804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 327 - J. Am. Stat. Assoc.">327</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This method can be used to study morphological and compositional changes at time and length scales far beyond what is possible with AIMD or MD.</p>
            
            <p>Recently, a kMC model has been developed to examine SEI growth in Li-metal systems at a level of detail far beyond prior studies.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0328" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0328_R_d63932372e4812" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 328 - J. Phys. Chem. C">328</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In this work, electrolyte reaction pathways and barriers were supplied from DFT calculations, and the Li metal/electrolyte interface was simulated at open circuit conditions. The model accurately simulated the growth of the SEI layer and provided novel insights about the composition and distribution of species. To date, no kMC studies concerning SIBs or the HC/Na–electrolyte interface have been published.</p>
            
            <p>Continuum models can also be applied to a variety of size- and timescales, depending on the system/properties of interest, and the desired level of precision. Species are represented implicitly as concentrations, rather than explicitly.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0329" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0329_R_d63932372e4820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 329 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">329</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0330" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0330_R_d63932372e4820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 330 - Prog. Energy">330</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The models are based on conservation equations, used in form of species, charge, energy and momentum balances with transport and source/sink terms, e.g., from reactions. A simple schematic is shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0025">25</a>. The recent rise of machine learning techniques has enabled the development of highly accurate continuum models by improving parametrization processes and experimental correlation, and will allow for more widespread application in the near future.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0331" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0331_R_d63932372e4830" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 331 - Batteries Supercaps">331</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This is the coarsest-grained and most computationally inexpensive method that we will discuss, it can provide spatially- and time-dependent system properties at larger scales than any of the previously mentioned methods. Continuum models are often used in conjunction with experiments, which allows for the identification of battery properties, such as SEI thickness, and processes, such as reaction kinetics.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0025"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/c50be984-ae99-43ed-9771-811a1293aebf/aenm202302830-fig-0025-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/c50be984-ae99-43ed-9771-811a1293aebf/aenm202302830-fig-0025-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/c87c3394-07fc-42b2-8997-c9ab75573ae6/aenm202302830-fig-0025-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/c50be984-ae99-43ed-9771-811a1293aebf/aenm202302830-fig-0025-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 25<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0025&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Sketch of the battery components at different scales. A battery is composed of multiple layers of single cells, which in turn are made of a porous structure, composed of electrode particles (yellow/black) held together by a conductive binder (gray), filled with a liquid electrolyte (white). The diagram also illustrates the electrochemical variables in the model: ion concentration in the electrolyte <i>C</i><sub>e</sub>, electrolyte potential <i>ϕ</i><sub>e</sub>, electrode potentials <i>ϕ</i><sub>n</sub> and <i>ϕ</i><sub>p</sub> and concentration of intercalated lithium <i>C</i><sub>n</sub> and <i>C</i><sub>p</sub> (yellow/black colormap). Reproduced under terms of the CC-BY license.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0330" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0330_R_d63932372e4875" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 330 - Prog. Energy">330</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Copyright 2022, Planna et&nbsp;al. Elsevier Ltd.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Continuum modeling has been employed to study SEI behavior during charge cycling of a Li-ion/graphite system.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0332" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0332_R_d63932372e4883" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 332 - ChemSusChem">332</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This model was able to determine a previously unknown mechanism of capacity fade and provide an explanation for the linear growth of the SEI. Other models have worked to model SEI growth<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0333" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0333_R_d63932372e4888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 333 - Electrochim. Acta">333</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and aging<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0334" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0334_R_d63932372e4893" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 334 - Batteries Supercaps">334</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> behaviors. Tanaka et&nbsp;al. have used continuum modeling to study the role of mechanical strain in SEI failure during the charging of lithium–silicon batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0335" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0335_R_d63932372e4899" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 335 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">335</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The application of continuum models for similar studies in SIBs is expected in the near future.</p>
            
            <p>Modeling can also be used to study vast amounts of data and systems, that would otherwise be impossible experimentally. Continuum models<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0336" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0336_R_d63932372e4907" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 336 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">336</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0337" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0337_R_d63932372e4907" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 337 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">337</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been used to predict optimal configurations, operating conditions, and safety properties at the cell and stack level. Dynamic multiscale models can be used to expedite the search for new battery materials by examining thousands of possible electrolytes and chemistries in order to narrow down the promising candidates for experimental testing.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0338" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0338_R_d63932372e4912" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 338 - J. Power Sources">338</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0091" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0091_R_d63932372e4912" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 91 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">91</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The results from experimental studies of these species can then be fed back into the model in order to improve the predictability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0339" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0339_R_d63932372e4917" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 339 - Adv. Energy Mater.">339</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0340" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0340_R_d63932372e4917" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 340 - Comput. Mater. Sci.">340</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Overall, computational modeling allows for the study of systems at scales and conditions that are not feasible with experiments. It serves to compliment and bridge together all of the previously discussed methods in order to develop a comprehensive understanding from the atomic scale to the industrial scale. We will discuss this in more detail in the next section.</p>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0160">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0160-title">4 Integration across Methods</h2>
         
         <p>The performance of SIBs and the behavior of the SEI/HC interface is influenced by the properties of every part of the electrochemical cell, and by phenomena occurring across many different time- and length-scales. The study of individual, isolated parts of the battery, at limited scales, provides information that is not necessarily accurate for the full system. All the methods we have discussed above are powerful, and provide valuable insight, but are limited in scope and scale when applied individually. In this section, we discuss possible approaches for integrating these methods together in order to overcome this limitation and develop a more holistic understanding of the HC interface and SIB behavior. We include <b>Figures</b> <a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0026">26</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0031">31</a> as a visual representation of how these integrated methodologies build this understanding, starting from the full cell.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0026"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/3f4dc52b-4fe8-4ffa-bf9e-01705af59c45/aenm202302830-fig-0026-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/3f4dc52b-4fe8-4ffa-bf9e-01705af59c45/aenm202302830-fig-0026-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/c8f5ec8c-4b3f-4ddd-9296-ed28263e9286/aenm202302830-fig-0026-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/3f4dc52b-4fe8-4ffa-bf9e-01705af59c45/aenm202302830-fig-0026-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 26<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0026&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic of general battery system, viewed at a "large" scale, with little fundamental information.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0027"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/ee28015d-ca0f-4c8b-a8b7-2229c0ff7802/aenm202302830-fig-0027-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/ee28015d-ca0f-4c8b-a8b7-2229c0ff7802/aenm202302830-fig-0027-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/8057f0bf-615d-4ca9-9ec1-394647b5a1ae/aenm202302830-fig-0027-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/ee28015d-ca0f-4c8b-a8b7-2229c0ff7802/aenm202302830-fig-0027-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 27<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0027&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic of larger-scale information that can be obtained by operando methods, the growing green border represents SEI growth, the thermometer, bubbles, and battery represent data available to microcalorimetry, OEMS, and EIS, respectively.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0028"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/2c2326a3-fba7-4586-b4d6-65d81e1e89fa/aenm202302830-fig-0028-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/2c2326a3-fba7-4586-b4d6-65d81e1e89fa/aenm202302830-fig-0028-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/03ea93e9-66b4-4c90-b858-ed6304030c16/aenm202302830-fig-0028-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/2c2326a3-fba7-4586-b4d6-65d81e1e89fa/aenm202302830-fig-0028-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 28<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0028&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematics of more precise data that can be obtained by pairing methods that correspond to the same properties (chemical/structural) at different scales. The left image represents the SEI with detailed chemical information, but no structural information. The middle image represents the SEI with detailed structural information, but no chemical information. The right image represents detailed structural information about the HC electrode particles, without information on the SEI.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0029"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0a9a13d1-9e4f-4d6c-93d8-5e262bf8cd94/aenm202302830-fig-0029-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/0a9a13d1-9e4f-4d6c-93d8-5e262bf8cd94/aenm202302830-fig-0029-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/11025b4a-c9d3-40fd-983b-3bb2e5d17a1d/aenm202302830-fig-0029-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0a9a13d1-9e4f-4d6c-93d8-5e262bf8cd94/aenm202302830-fig-0029-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 29<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0029&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of the SEI on a HC particle as can be derived from experiments.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0030"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/eabf1969-07c8-437f-af13-b74437fc7083/aenm202302830-fig-0030-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/eabf1969-07c8-437f-af13-b74437fc7083/aenm202302830-fig-0030-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/e7c11e96-7d61-47ce-93a6-cb1083592470/aenm202302830-fig-0030-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/eabf1969-07c8-437f-af13-b74437fc7083/aenm202302830-fig-0030-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 30<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0030&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Atomic scale information on the different types of Na<sup>+</sup> insertion behavior in HC: Metallic pore filling (blue), intercalation between layers (green) and adsorption on edges (red).</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202302830-fig-0031"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/a57023ed-09af-423d-9fff-3956510b130c/aenm202302830-fig-0031-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/a57023ed-09af-423d-9fff-3956510b130c/aenm202302830-fig-0031-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/f47e613b-c282-42e7-b6e8-5ed348afb144/aenm202302830-fig-0031-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/a57023ed-09af-423d-9fff-3956510b130c/aenm202302830-fig-0031-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 31<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202302830-fig-0031&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Representation of SEI including detailed structural and chemical information, on a particle with well-defined structure.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>Operando methods are vital for obtaining insight at practical size- and timescales but are typically limited to seeing only a portion of the cell function/behavior/properties. They can be paired with other operando methods in order to overcome this and develop a broader understanding of the cell properties and performance. EIS analysis is almost always used in combination with other methods. It pairs very well with OEMS because both methods work operando and can be performed in parallel on the same system.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0341" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0341_R_d63932372e5062" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 341 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">341</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These measurements can be used to correlate the reactions observed in OEMS to changes in larger-scale properties, such as SEI resistance and the degradation state of the cell. The substrate curvature technique works also operando and is able to detect processes at the interface/SEI,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0342" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0342_R_d63932372e5067" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 342 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">342</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> this can be coupled with the OEMS/IS methods to correspond SEI growth to specific reactions and changes in battery performance.</p>
         
         <p>The numerous materials composing a battery cell undergo a number of physicochemical reactions, each of which induce a measurable change in Gibb's free energy. Single electrode microcalorimetry can detect the precise times when these changes occur but is not able to determine information about the reaction itself. OEMS/EIS/CV techniques can be used to supplement microcalorimetry measurements and determine precise timelines for reactions and develop clearer understanding of the relationship between specific reactions and changes in cell behavior.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0269_R_d63932372e5075" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">269</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Operando methods are typically too coarse-grained to develop detailed conclusions about underlying phenomena, but they can be combined with more precise in situ or postmortem techniques to create a holistic picture of the processes under investigation. Operando measurements can be used to determine the points of time during charge cycling when significant events occur. In situ and postmortem techniques can then be applied to the cell at these points to determine the underlying behavior and mechanisms. OEMS is able to study battery reactivity operando but faces challenges with the precise determination of the reaction chemistry and is unable to distinguish the component of the cell where reactions occur. OEMS measurements are often used in combination with surface chemistry analysis methods, such as XPS, to correlate the observed reactivity and degradation products to their respective electrodes and location thereon. By extension, all of the operando methods discussed in the previous paragraph can be paired with detailed chemical and structural information from surface sensitive techniques like SEM/SPM/XPS/ToF-SIMS/DFT<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0228_R_d63932372e5082" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Electrochem. Sci. Adv.">228</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0269_R_d63932372e5082" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.">269</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0342" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0342_R_d63932372e5082" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 342 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">342</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0345" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0345_R_d63932372e5082" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 345 - J. Power Sources">345</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> in order to determine the specific underlying phenomena that correspond to the overall cell performance.</p>
         
         <p>In the case of STEM, normally high-energy electron beams are used, so that the electron dose dictates whether the structure is changed. Battery materials can be beam-sensitive, i.e., their structure may be disrupted (amorphization) or destroyed, and thus the conductivity can be altered.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0346" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0346_R_d63932372e5090" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 346 - Microsc. Microanal.">346</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Formation of secondary electrons during SEM operation is always paired with the emergence of element-specific X-rays providing information on segregation, diffusion or transformation of active species stemming from electrochemical processes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0150" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0150_R_d63932372e5097" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 150 - Chem.
