Geol.">150</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> While this process does not harm the sample surface, the FIB tomography option cleaves the sample surface and thus destructively provides insights into the bulk material.</p>
         
         <p>The substrate curvature method probes the entire bulk simultaneously, and the measured stresses strongly depend on the volumetric changes and phase transformations of crystalline structures. XRD is able to observe these phenomena and can be combined with substrate curvature to obtain high-speed and high-resolution stress/strain and local crystal structure data. XRD can also be used to relate specific structural changes to energy changes observed with microcalorimetry.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0347" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0347_R_d63932372e5105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 347 - Adv. Sustainable Syst.">347</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> AFM combined with OEMS/EIS/CV gives access to in situ and operando studies, providing correlated structure-reactivity information.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0228_R_d63932372e5110" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Electrochem. Sci. Adv.">228</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The nanostructure of the SEI, in addition to its chemical properties, has a direct impact on its stability and passivation properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0348" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0348_R_d63932372e5118" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 348 - J. Phys. Chem. C">348</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>XPS allows for precise qualitative and quantitative chemical analysis of interphases but cannot easily differentiate between the organic species that are commonly produced during electrolyte decomposition. It is also limited in scale; only small regions of a surface can be studied, and only the first few nanometers of a surface emit photoelectrons, making it very sensitive to the upper layers of the surface.</p>
         
         <p>XPS can give information about the chemical and the oxidation state as well as on the electronic structure. But it is not possible to detect where the accumulation of certain elements or the change in the electronic structure appears. Here, ToF-SIMS and STEM deliver the advantage for combining spectroscopy and spectrometry on the scales of microns with real-space imaging at the atomic-scale.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0349" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0349_R_d63932372e5127" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 349 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">349</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> ToF-SIMS suffers from the matrix effect, which only allows for qualitative and semi-quantitative studies without complex calibration routines; XPS does not suffer from this effect, and thus can obtain complimentary quantitative data for the ToF-SIMS study.</p>
         
         <p>Given the achievable spatial resolution and the fact that in situ measurements can be performed, AFM and other methods from the family of SPM techniques can contribute and complement microscopic methods like SEM that are short of 3D morphology information and are usually only performed in high vacuum.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0228_R_d63932372e5135" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Electrochem. Sci. Adv.">228</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Reaching even smaller length-scales, STEM experiments can be enabled by FIB technique which is ensuring the necessary sample quality. In the case of Na-based batteries the preparation must be done under cryo-conditions to avoid diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> due to the influence of the ion-beam.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0350" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0350_R_d63932372e5144" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 350 - Microscopy">350</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Solid-state NMR and MRI are able to compliment and validate XRD, SEM, TEM, and XPS characterization results.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0296" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0296_R_d63932372e5149" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - Chem. Rev.">296</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>XRD analysis is mainly used to study the atomic scale structure of the HC in regard to the sodiation/desodiation processes and is thus complementary to other methods being sensitive to local order and defects. In particular, the combination of Raman spectroscopy and XRD, especially if performed in situ or operando, shows high promise to unravel fine details of changes in periodic order as well as on the relevance of defect sites.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0028_R_d63932372e5156" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - ACS Energy Lett.">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> For instance, the layer extension <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> can be assessed by XRD as well as by Raman spectroscopy. Moreover, such methodology has already been performed on hard carbon nano fibers used for sodiation studies, revealing insight into the different storage mechanisms.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e5164" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Here, the changes in the XRD data upon sodiation were accompanied by a red-shift of the G-band in Raman spectroscopy, reflecting elongation of the C-C blond length.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0351" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0351_R_d63932372e5170" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 351 - Adv. Energy Mater.">351</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Also, Also, the D-band declines during sodiation,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0241" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0241_R_d63932372e5175" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Small">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which may be caused by Na<sup>+</sup> adsorption on surface of graphene stacks, and which thus may complement small-angle X-ray scattering analysis<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0245" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0245_R_d63932372e5183" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 245 - Adv. Energy Mater.">245</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> probing the pore filling process.</p>
         
         <p>Different techniques can also be paired together to overcome practical limitations of study, such as constraints on size, material properties, and sample environment.</p>
         
         <p>On the scales of below 100 nm up to 100 mm, ToF-SIMS provides information about lateral and in-depth distribution of substructured surface layers. The ballistic impact on the surface during the ToF-SIMS ionization process can damage (alter) some sensitive chemical compounds. Surface sensitive techniques, like XPS, can be applied to obtain the initial chemical state, before the sample is damaged. Here, the chemical states must be investigated before the sample is damaged by the primary ion beam from the ToF-SIMS.</p>
         
         <p>ToF-SIMS and standard XPS measurements traditionally require UHV conditions, which disallows the use of liquid-containing samples, and thus can only be used postmortem or loosely for in situ examination (when samples are cryogenically frozen during analysis). Here, (near) ambient pressure XPS measurements provide a potential pathway to obtain more realistic data on solid/liquid interfaces in batteries with and without electrochemical bias.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0352" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0352_R_d63932372e5196" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 352 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">352</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0353" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0353_R_d63932372e5196" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 353 - Nat. Commun.">353</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Other liquid- and gas-sensitive methods, such as OEMS, can provide information about the remaining reaction products from initial SEI formation as well as continuous degradation.</p>
         
         <p>The geometry of the investigated surface plays a significant role as the quality of obtained information decreases and eventually vanishes depending on surface roughness. Topographic effects limiting the resolution of ToF-SIMS measurements can be related to morphology investigations by SPM techniques and SEM imaging in order to regain realistic information.</p>
         
         <p>Computational models are paired with many different experimental methods in order to provide detailed insight on processes that are otherwise too fast, small, or complex, to be observed experimentally.</p>
         
         <p>DFT is often paired with chemical analysis techniques, such as OEMS and XPS, in order to delineate the reactive species and develop reaction mechanisms for the experimentally-observed products.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0354" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0354_R_d63932372e5208" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 354 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">354</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0355" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0355_R_d63932372e5208" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 355 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">355</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> AIMD and DFT calculations are also frequently used in combination with XPS and Raman spectroscopy in order to determine the surface conditions and reaction mechanisms that produce the SEI species observed experimentally.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0356" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0356_R_d63932372e5213" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 356 - J. Power Sources">356</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0357" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0357_R_d63932372e5213" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 357 - J. Phys. Chem. Lett.">357</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Larger scale simulations can provide insight on structural data and transport processes. SPM techniques can be paired with MD to determine the interfacial nanostructures and complex molecular phenomena that contribute to more stable electrodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0358" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0358_R_d63932372e5221" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 358 - Nat. Mater.">358</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> MD simulations can also provide atom-scale transport behavior and diffusion rates to correspond with solid state NMR studies.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0359" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0359_R_d63932372e5226" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 359 - Curr. Opin. Electrochem.">359</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> MD and reverse Monte Carlo calculations can be coupled with XRD in order to develop an atomistic understanding of the HC microstructure and Na<sup>+</sup> insertion behavior. DFT calculations can then determine the specific HC characteristics and structures that contribute to more effective ion storage.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0056" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0056_R_d63932372e5234" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 56 - Adv. Energy Mater.">56</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Computational models can also be applied to develop a clearer physical understanding of operando techniques. EIS is often difficult to precisely interpret due to the overlapping of different frequency regions (processes) and sensitivity to minute changes in the cell. Witt et&nbsp;al. have developed a continuum model of experimental EIS measurements, as well as discharge in full- and half cells, in order to correlate experimentally observed cell behavior to specific SEI properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0334" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0334_R_d63932372e5241" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 334 - Batteries Supercaps">334</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This model is able to overcome the challenge of experimentally overlapping data and delineate individual ongoing processes in the cell.</p>
         
         <p>Multiple modeling methods can be combined in order to bridge the precision of finer methods to the scale of coarser methods. kMC methods can be coupled with continuum models to allow for atomistic insight and reaction information to be obtained at large timescales.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0360" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0360_R_d63932372e5249" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 360 - Comput. Chem. Eng.">360</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Advances in processing hardware and machine-learning are allowing for modelling to be applied more rigorously than ever before. The availability of robust DFT parameters is often the bottleneck for larger-scale methods like MD and kMC. Machine learning methods and kMC principles can be applied to DFT calculations in order to accelerate the search for these reaction barriers and parameters.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0361" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0361_R_d63932372e5256" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 361 - J. Chem. Phys.">361</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Machine learning can also be applied to accelerate the aforementioned search for electrolyte and electrode materials, and to improve the precision/accuracy of experiment-based models, like those of EIS.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0362" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0362_R_d63932372e5261" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 362 - Mater. Adv.">362</a>, <a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0363" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0363_R_d63932372e5261" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 363 - Mater. Rep. Energy">363</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>The integration of all these methods, both experimental and theoretical, enables the full understanding of the fundamental properties of the HC interface and its relationship with the overall performance of SIBs.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0170">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0170-title">5 Conclusion</h2>
         
         <p>The major issues currently limiting SIB technologies are capacity fade and cell degradation, primarily due to instabilities in the HC electrode-electrolyte interface that induce the formation of ineffective SEIs. These instabilities are simultaneously influenced by processes that occur across many timescales at all parts of the electrochemical cell. The properties of the electrolyte and HC anode have the strongest influence on the stability of the SEI, and the large inconsistency between different HC samples makes it even more difficult to obtain clear and reliable information (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202302830-fig-0030">30</a>).</p>
         
         <p>Electronic information about the battery cell is provided by EIS measurements, while the single electrodes can be probed by SPM techniques. Continuum models are able to simulate and clarify this data.</p>
         
         <p>Chemical information about the gas-phase reaction products of processes occurring during formation of the SEI in electrochemical cells is provided by OEMS, while GC-MS or NMR provide insights in the liquid-electrolyte phase. Microcalorimetric measurements of thermodynamic data can help pinpoint when different chemical reactions occur. XPS, ssNMR, and ToF-SIMS give detailed information about the solid products, including chemical identity as well as lateral and depth profiles of chemical compounds. DFT, AIMD, and kMC calculations provide atom-scale insight on reactivity.</p>
         
         <p>Physical events that generate changes in the Gibbs free energy of the system can also be detected by microcalorimetric studies. Operando stress curvature measurements reveal information about the fundamental mechanical properties of the electrode and SEI over the course of cycling. SEM can help visualize the difference between separate states of a single electrode. STEM and XRD investigations show the smallest entity of physical-structural bulk properties, namely the crystal structure. MD calculations are able to determine atomic structures and ionic transport behavior.</p>
         
         <p>The techniques discussed here do not constitute a comprehensive list; there are many other powerful methods available for the study of battery systems, including: accelerating rate calorimetry,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0364" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0364_R_d63932372e5289" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 364 - J. Energy Chem.">364</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> differential scanning calorimetry,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0365" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0365_R_d63932372e5294" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 365 - Electrochem. Commun.">365</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> dilatometry,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0366" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0366_R_d63932372e5299" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 366 - Energy Technol.">366</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> cyclic voltammetry,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0367" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0367_R_d63932372e5305" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 367 - J. Electrochem. Sci. Technol.">367</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and many more.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0368" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0368_R_d63932372e5310" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 368 - Adv. Energy Mater.">368</a>-<a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0372" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0372_R_d63932372e5310" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 372 - Adv. Energy Mater.">372</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The methods and combinations we selected for this perspective are intended to provide an outline of the different scales and properties that can be studied in SIBs, in order to provide a clear overarching idea for new researchers and are summarized in <b>Table</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202302830-tbl-0002">2</a>.</p>
         
         <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202302830-tbl-0002">
            
            
            
            
            <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  2.
                    </span>List of the herein described analytical methods for the analysis of sodium-ion batteries with a focus on SEI investigation</header>
            
            
            
            <div class="article-table-content-wrapper" tabindex="0">
               <table class="table article-section__table">
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  <thead>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Method</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Requirements</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Obtained info/strength</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Missing info</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Complementary method filling the gap</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Scale/Resolution</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">In situ <i>/</i> operando <i>/</i> postmortem</th>
                        
                        <th class="bottom-bordered-cell center-aligned">Time/difficulty</th>
                        </tr>
                     </thead>
                  
                  <tbody>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">OEMS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Cell or setup allowing to sample produced gas</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Chemical decomposition mechanisms, progression of degradation processes as function of operating conditions and cell design</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Structural info, solid/liquid degradation products, single degradation kinetics</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Ab initio and continuum simulations for kinetics/mechanisms, NMR for electrolyte composition, ToF-SIMS/XPS for SEI composition</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Ideal and technical electrode level, small and large cells</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Operando</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Seconds to hours difficulty to quantify single reaction rates</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">EIS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Potentiostat with electrochemical impedance module</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">In theory fundamental electrochemical parameters, e.g., double layer capacitance, diffusion coefficients, reaction kinetics)/fast data acquisition &amp; quick to setup</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Electrode morphologies</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">XPS, SPM, FIB/SEM, microcalorimetry, simulations</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">From cell to pack level (coin cells to pouch/prismatic formats)</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>In situ</p>
                           <p>(stationary EIS)</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Minutes to hours/easy for simple spectra comparison challenging for in-depth analysis (particularly batteries)</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Substrate curvature</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Sample rigidly attached to a ceramic substrate (purely elastic)</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Mechanical stress caused by electrode operation/electrochemical reactions with very high sensitivity</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Structural and chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">XRD, XPS, TOF-SIMS, SECM</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>Sample dimensions: 5–</p>
                           <p>20 mm; resolution. changes on the level of sub-monolayers</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Operando</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Sample and cell preparatio<i>n</i> ≈1 d, measurement time minutes up to weeks</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">ToF-SIMS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Smooth surface, solid, UHV</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Highly resolved lateral/3D element/fragment distribution, sensitivity</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>XPS, SPM, GC</p>
                           <p>EIS</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">50 nm–several mm</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Postmortem</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Measurement times from minutes to days, very expensive</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">XPS/HAXPS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Solid, UHV, preferably smooth</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">High surface sensitivity, qualitative and (semi)quantitative chemical info, oxidation states, chemical bonding, electronic structure</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Lateral distribution</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">ToF-SIMS, SPM, GC, OEMS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>lateral ≈5–</p>
                           <p>500 µm</p>
                           <p>vertical ≈ 1–</p>
                           <p>50 nm (with hard X-rays)</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Postmortem, for solid state even operando, with liquids: ambient -pressure XPS for in situ/operando</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Minutes to hours, synchrotron measurements only proposal-based</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">FIB/SEM</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Protective Pt coatings, sample preparation like embedding for tomography</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Porosity, microstructure, coupled with EDS and EBSD additional information on element composition, insights on crystallographic information, e.g., grain orientations and grain architectures</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">ToF-SIMS, XPS, STEM</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>≈10 nm–</p>
                           <p>400 µm</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Postmortem</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Hours-days for sample preparation, actual measurement: hours, 3D reconstruction: hours to days</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">SPM</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Preferably smooth surface</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Surface morphology, ionic fluxes, electrochemical properties, electrical conductivity, electrochemical activity, nanomechanical properties</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">XPS, STEM, SEM,</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>&gt;0.1 nm lateral-res.</p>
                           <p>few Å height-res.</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">In situ, postmortem</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Minutes to hours</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">XRD</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Sample amount ≈50 mg at minimum (powder); for in situ experiments special cells being transparent for X-rays or neutrons</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Crystallographic info mainly on HC: interlayer spacing, dimension and disorder of the graphene stacks; presence of elemental Na.</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Raman spectroscopy, XPS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Few Å to nm</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">In situ, operando, postmortem</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Minutes to hours</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">STEM</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Solid state sample, high vacuum compatible (except with dedicated holder), to be thinned to electron transparency</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">2D/3D nanoscale morphology, atomic structure, semiquantitative nanoscale chemical composition, nanoscale oxidation state</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Bulk properties, quantitative chemical composition, light element detection, surface sensitivity, electrochemical characterization</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Light optical microscopy, SEM, FIB, XPS, ToF-SIMS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>0.1 nm–</p>
                           <p>≈30 µm</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Postmortem, with dedicated holders also in situ or operando</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>Sample prep.: hours–days</p>
                           <p>measurements: hours–days</p>
                           <p>data analysis: hours–days</p></td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Microcalorimetry</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Thin electrode</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Heat evolution during electrochemical reaction; reaction entropy</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Structural info, chemical info</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">SPM, XRD, EIS, XPS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">1–10 mm</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">In situ</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Complete experiment: days to weeks, single heat measurement &lt; 10 s</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">NMR</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Superconducting homogeneous magnet with electronics and detectors used to analyze materials of about 1 to 100 mg (depending on density and sample-holder/rotor size)</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Site specific differentiation/quantification, local structure, mobility, formation, transfer, (electrochemical and side) reaction, and degradation mechanisms</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Interphases, ionic states of elements, nonmagnetic sites (nuclei)</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">XRD, OEMS, GC, SEM, TEM, XAS, PDF, XPS, and EIS</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Electrode level to cells (usually plastic bag cell) with local structure resolution below 1 nm</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">In situ, operando and postmortem</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Minutes to hours</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Modeling</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">
                           <p>Different modeling techniques are limited to different scales.</p>
                           <p>Many techniques require significant amounts of input data specific to the system in question</p></td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Degradation, transport and insertion mechanisms and kinetics, SEI evolution and degradation on HC as function of material and operation, model design can be tailored for research question</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">Structural and chemical info at different scales</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">All experimental measurements</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">From nm to cm</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">N/A</td>
                        
                        <td class="center-aligned">varies significantly depending on modeling method</td>
                        </tr>
                     </tbody>
                  </table>
            </div>
            
            
            <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
         </div>
         
         <p>Herein, we provide an overview of necessary interconnectable techniques aimed at the multiscale investigation of the SEI on HC electrodes in SIB. There is no single method that is capable of investigating all of these scales simultaneously. Multiscale studies, that account for simultaneous processes, multiple parts of the cell, and use consistent HC reference materials, are needed in order to provide a complete picture of SIB behavior. In situ and operando measurements of the processes in SIBs and their effects must be correlated to their underlying chemical and physical phenomena at all scales, from cell-level to atomistic, by coupling multiple experimental and computational methods in single studies. Continuous collaboration between well-connected academic groups with complementary expertise is needed to overcome the logistical challenges posed by multiscale investigations of chemically consistent systems.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0180">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0180-title">6 Experimental Section</h2>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0190">
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0200">
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0210">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0210-title"> Substrate Curvature</h4>
                  
                  <p>For the operando stress measurement, a borosilicate glass cantilever (155&nbsp;µm thick, 14&nbsp;mm long and 5 mm wide) was used. It was coated with a 25&nbsp;nm tungsten film that served as a current collector and then spray coated with a hard carbon composite electrode. The coating consisted of 85&nbsp;% hard carbon (Kuranode hard carbon 5&nbsp;µm type II, Kuraray, Japan), 5&nbsp;% CMC binder and 10&nbsp;% conductive carbon (Vulcan XC72R). The curvature measurement was performed in a test setup that was developed within the group.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0106_R_d63932372e5790" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Power Sources">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It is optimized for measurements inside a custom-made electrochemical test cell and exhibits accurate temperature stabilization. The cantilever was clamped in the test cell, which was then filled by about 0.6&nbsp;mL of electrolyte containing 1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> dissolved in EC:PC (1:1). It contained less than 3&nbsp;ppm of water (Karl Fischer Titration) after drying for more than a week with 4&nbsp;Å molecular sieve (Sigma-Aldrich). Na metal foils served as counter and reference electrodes. The test cell was hermetically sealed by mounting a sapphire window to its front and then moved from the argon filled glove box into the curvature setup. Electrochemical experiments were performed using a commercial battery cycler (VMP3, Bio-Logic SAS). During the stress measurement, two laser beams (Schäfter + Kirchhoff 51nanoFCM) entered and left the test cell through the transparent sapphire window and were reflected at the back of the cantilever. To minimize stress concentrations related to clamping, two laser beams were used. The position of both reflected beams was recorded by a CMOS camera with a 1’’ chip (Pixelink PL-B782F) located at a distance of 208&nbsp;mm from the cantilever. A Labview program recorded the data from the camera for both laser spots (center of mass of the intensity distribution) at 40 Hz as well as the electrochemical data from the VMP3. Simple trigonometry was used to calculate the deflection angles and radius of curvature of the cantilever in the region between both laser beams. The composite electrode contained materials with very different thermal expansion coefficients (polymer, metal, and ceramic). To suppress curvature due to temperature, the setup was located inside a thermally isolated box with a Peltier-based active temperature control (also controlled by the Labview program) that limits temperature fluctuations below ± 10 mK.</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0220">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0220-title"> OEMS</h4>
                  
                  <p>For the OEMS measurements a test setup developed by the own group was used.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0085" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0085_R_d63932372e5808" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 85">85</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In the PAT-cell gas by EL-cell was assembled in a glovebox under argon gas with an electrode (consisting of 85% hard carbon, 10% carbon black and 5% PVDF binder), an NVP electrode by the Binder Group and 150 µL of 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC:PC (1:1) electrolyte. The insulation sleeve also contained a sodium reference ring.</p>
                  
                  <p>The cell was attached to a constant argon flow via a mass flow controller (EL-Flow Prestige FG-200CV, BRONKHORST) to the mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 320 OC2 (PTM81217121), PFEIFFER VACUUM). Measurement data were recorded with the proprietary software PV MassSpec. The potentiostat (Gamry Interface 5000, GAMRY Instruments) was used to conduct two formation cycles (charge and discharge) at 1/10C.</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0230">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0230-title"> EIS</h4>
                  
                  <p>Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed on a 50 × 10<sup>−3</sup> <span class="smallCaps">m</span> aqueous solution of K<sub>4</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>/K<sub>3</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub> with an additional 10 × 10<sup>−3</sup> <span class="smallCaps">m</span> K<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> supporting electrolyte. The measurement was carried out under ambient conditions in a three-electrode setup (10 mL glass vessel with PTFE lid to fix electrodes) using a Biologic SP-200 potentiostat. Reference electrode: Ag/AgCl in 3 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> KCl; working electrode: Pt disc electrode (1.6 mm diameter) and counter electrode (Pt wire). Data analysis performed with RelaxIS3 (rhd instruments, version 3.0.20 Build 19).</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0240">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0240-title"> ToF-SIMS</h4>
                  
                  <p>HC electrodes with a mass loading of 1.5 mg cm<sup>−2</sup> for time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) measurements were electrochemically cycled versus Na-metal in PC electrolyte with 1 <span class="smallCaps">m</span> NaClO<sub>4</sub> conducting salt and 2% FEC additive at 0.1C. The cells were disassembled and handled under argon atmosphere in a glovebox and transported in a VCT 500 shuttle (Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany) under inert gas conditions to the SIMS machine. ToF-SIMS depth profiles were performed in positive ion mode using a ToF.SIMS 6 (Iontof GmbH, Muenster, Germany) machine, which is equipped with a Bi nanoprobe analysis gun and was operated at 15 keV. A pulsed Bi<sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup> primary ion beam scanned a surface area of 50 × 50 µm<sup>2</sup> with 128 × 128 pixels at a cycle time of 100 µs until a total dose density of 2.74 × 10<sup>13</sup> ions cm<sup>−2</sup> was reached. Charge compensation was carried out with a low energetic electron flood gun. The achieved mass resolution was better than <i>m</i>/∆<i>m</i> = 6000 (FWHM) at <i>m/z</i> 62.982 (Na<sub>2</sub>OH<sup>+</sup>). For data analysis SurfaceLab 7.3 software (IONTOF GmbH, Muenster, Germany) was used by which the surface spectra were calibrated to the mass signals of the fragments Na<sub>2</sub>OH<sup>+</sup>, Na<sub>2</sub>F<sup>+</sup> and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup>.</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0250">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0250-title"> FIB/SEM Tomography</h4>
                  
                  <p>FIB/SEM tomography was performed using a Helios Nanolab 600 (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). The gallium ion beam was operated at 30&nbsp;kV. The HC particle within a composite electrode was covered with a protective platinum layer via ion beam induced deposition (IBID) using the precursor methylcyclopentadienyl trimethyl platinum (C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>16</sub>Pt). Cross-section and trenches alongside the particle were prepared prior to FIB/SEM tomography. Imaging and slice and view were conducted using the software package “Auto Slice &amp; View G3” (version 1.0.0.1236, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). Secondary electron images were acquired at 0.69&nbsp;nA and 3&nbsp;kV with a pixel size of 16.6 × 16.6&nbsp;nm<sup>2</sup> using immersion mode and the through-the-lens-detector (TLD). After each image a slice of 30&nbsp;nm thickness was removed from the particle front, in total a stack of 332 images was acquired.</p>
                  
                  <p>For the 3D reconstruction of the particle, the obtained image stack was processed using Avizo Lite (version 9.1.0, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA), i.e., the images were manually aligned and filtered using edge-preserving smoothing, binarized and segmented using a threshold. The segmentation of pore space within the HC particle was revised manually afterwards.</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0260">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0260-title"> SPM</h4>
                  
                  <p>The approach curves and corresponding SECM mappings of the HC composite electrodes (pristine and 40 cycles in 1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span>&nbsp;NaClO<sub>4</sub>/PC, 0.1 C) were recorded with 0.01&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span> ferrocene as redox mediator in acetonitrile/0.1&nbsp;<span class="smallCaps">m</span>&nbsp;TBAPF<sub>6</sub>. A Pt UME (<i>r</i> = 1.5&nbsp;µm) was used as the working electrode, a leakless Ag/AgCl (eDAQ Pty Ltd, Australia) electrode served as the reference and a Pt wire as the counter electrode. All measurements were controlled with the Sensolytics SECM software (version 2.2.3.3, Sensolytics GmbH, Germany). A potential of 0.5&nbsp;V was applied at the UME tip. The UME was approached with 2&nbsp;µm&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> toward the HC composite electrode surface at three positions for tilt correction. Afterwards, a mapping of 100 × 100&nbsp;µm<sup>2</sup> was recorded with a step size of 3&nbsp;µm and tip velocity of 2 µm&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. After the mapping, approach curves were performed with the same parameters as described above.</p>
                  </section>
               
               <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202302830-sec-0270">
                  
                  <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section4" id="aenm202302830-sec-0270-title"> XPS</h4>
                  
                  <p>X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out in a commercial UHV system (SPECS) with a base pressure of 2 × 10<sup>−10</sup> mbar. It consists of two chambers, one containing an Aarhus-type STM/AFM system (SPECS Aarhus SPM150 with a Colibri sensor), the other one is equipped with an X-ray source (SPECS XR50, Al-K<sub>α</sub> and Mg-K<sub>α</sub>), a He lamp (SPECS UVS 300) and a hemispherical analyzer (SPECS, DLSEGD-Phoibos-Has3500) for XPS and UPS measurements. The XP spectra were recorded using monochromatized Al K<sub>α</sub> radiation (<i>hν</i><sub>0</sub> = 1486.6 eV) at a power of 400 W (<i>U</i> = 15 kV, <i>I</i> = 26.7 mA), with a pass energy of 20 eV for all detail spectra. All spectra were recorded at an electron emission angle of 0° with respect to the surface normal. The binding energy (BE) scale was calibrated by setting the position of the main C 1s peak of the substrate to 284.6 eV.</p>
                  
                  <p>Samples for XPS measurements were prepared by carbon spray deposition on a Cu foil,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202302830-bib-0133" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202302830-bib-0133_R_d63932372e5975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 133 - Batteries Supercaps">133</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which was glued with conductive silver paste on the Ta sample holder. The sample was then transferred to the spectrometer in a hermetically sealed transport box excluding contact to air and introduced via a load lock into the UHV system. Afterward, the sample was heated to 300 °C (measured at the manipulator) to remove volatile contaminants.</p>
                  </section>
               </section>
            </section>
         </section>
      <div class="article-section__content">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202302830-sec-0280-title"> Acknowledgements</h2>
         
         <p>D.S. and K.H. contributed equally to this work. This work contributes to the research performed at CELEST (Center for Electrochemical Energy Storage Ulm-Karlsruhe) and was funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG) under Project ID 390874152 (POLiS Cluster of Excellence). The authors extend the thanks to Elisa Monte for her valuable contribution in creating the TOC figure for this paper.</p>
         
         <p>Open access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL.</p>
         
         <ol></ol>
      </div>

         </section>

                        <span><a                   <li data-bib-id="aenm202302830-bib-0006"><span class="bullet">6</span><span class="author">M. Á. Muñoz-Márquez</span>, <span class="author">M. Interfaces</i> <span class="pubYear">2022</span>,  <span class="vol">9</span>, 2101773.
                     <div class="extra-links getFTR"><span class="hidden data-doi">10.1002/admi.202101773</span><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div>
                        <span><a href="/servlet/linkout?suffix=null&amp;dbid=32&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830&amp;key=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB38Xht1Kmsbo%253D&amp;getFTLinkType=true&amp;doiForPubOfPage=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830&amp;refDoi=10.1002%2Fadmi.202101773&amp;linkType=COI&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT&amp;linkLocation=Reference" href="/servlet/linkout?suffix=null&amp;dbid=128&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830&amp;key=WOS%3A000741337500001&amp;getFTLinkType=true&amp;doiForPubOfPage=10.1002%2Faenm.202302830&amp;refDoi=10.1002%2Fadmi.202101773&amp;linkType=ISI&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT&amp;linkLocation=Reference" onclick="newWindow(this.href);return false" class="visitable" target="_blank">Web of Science®</a></span><span><a class="google-scholar visitable"
